9,1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
column2: Overview of Define Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation,Use the Define Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation task list to streamline your setup configurations. The rapid implementation task list minimizes the time used to complete your key configurations and enables the day-to-day use of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud applications.,Header for Page 9

column1: 9,1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
column2: Overview of Define Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation,"To create an implementation project that includes the Define Accounting Entry Configuration for Rapid Implementation task list, use the Manage Implementation Projects page in the Setup and Maintenance work area. You can modify the task list as needed and assign and track each task.",Header for Page 9

column1: 9,1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud
column2: Overview of Define Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation,Note: You are not restricted to only the setup configuration in the rapid implementation task list. You can manually add the standard Oracle Fusion Accounting Hub offering task lists and tasks to your rapid implementation project.,Header for Page 9

column1: 10,Create an Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Rapid Implementation Project,"Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:",Header for Page 10
10,"Create an Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Rapid Implementation Project
column2: Creating the Implementation Project To create an implementation project, follow these steps:","1. From the Setup and Maintenance work area, open the Setup page. You must have the Manage Implementation Project ( ASM_MANAGE_IMPLEMENTATION_PROJECT_PRIV) privilege. 2. From the Setup page, open the panel drawer and select Manage Implementation Projects . 3. Click the Create icon. 4. Enter a meaningful name and a brief description to describe your project. 5. Optionally, assign the project to a user and specify a start date. 6. Click Save and Open Project when you complete your selection. 7. You can begin to assign the tasks to the appropriate users. Select and add the Define Fusion Accounting Hub Configuration for Rapid Implementation task list.",Header for Page 10

column1: 10,"Create an Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Rapid Implementation Project

column1: 11,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 11
11,,Chapter 1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Header for Page 11
11,,Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features,Header for Page 11
11,Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features,"Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud provides a complete set of accounting tools and unparalleled access to financial data, including:",Header for Page 11
11,Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features,Oracle General Ledger features that provide:,Header for Page 11

11,Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features,Journal entry import and creation Real time balances from a balances cube Accounting controls Close functionality Cross-ledger intercompany balancing Calculation Manager for the definition of allocation rules using complex formulas Automatic generation of allocation journals Enhanced journal approval Year-end process management,Header for Page 11
11,Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features
column2: Journal entry import and creation Real time balances from a balances cube Accounting controls Close functionality Cross-ledger intercompany balancing Calculation Manager for the definition of allocation rules using complex formulas Automatic generation of allocation journals Enhanced journal approval Year-end process management,Oracle Financial Reporting that provides:,Header for Page 11

column1: 11,Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features,"Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",Header for Page 11
11,"Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts","Accounting transformation enables you to create subledger accounting rules that provide flexible transformation of transaction and reference information from diverse, non-Oracle, industry applications into accurate, detailed, auditable accounting entries. The subledger accounting journals generated for non-Oracle applications are stored in a subledger accounting repository that is shared with the subledger accounting journals generated by Oracle Fusion Subledger Accounting for the subledgers such as Payables, Receivables, Assets and Inventory.",Header for Page 11

column1: 11,"Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",Related Topics,Header for Page 11

column1: 11,"Overview of Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Features
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works,Header for Page 11

column1: 11,,How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works,Header for Page 11
11,"How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud process begins by using financial data from any or all of the following:,Header for Page 11

column1: 11,"How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",Non-Oracle source systems including transaction and reference information from industry-specific applications.,Header for Page 11

column1: 11,"How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",Oracle Fusion subledgers including subledger journals.,Header for Page 11

column1: 11,"How Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Works
column2: Embedded balances cube functionality Multidimensional, online analytical processing of financial information Ability to slice and dice data across dimensions Drill up, down, and across on any parent level within the chart of accounts",3,Header for Page 11

column1: 12,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 12
12,,Chapter 1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Header for Page 12
12,,"Oracle E-Business Suite, Oracle PeopleSoft, and Oracle JD Edwards general ledgers including account balances.",Header for Page 12
12,,The Accounting Hub process ends with complete reporting and analysis solutions.,Header for Page 12
12,,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,Header for Page 12
12,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,The Accounting Hub contains the following components:,Header for Page 12
12,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,Accounting transformation to transform external source data.,Header for Page 12
12,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,Oracle General Ledger to enter and post journals including allocations.,Header for Page 12
12,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,Oracle Financial Reporting Center for reporting and analysis.,Header for Page 12
12,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,Integration with Oracle Planning and Budgeting Cloud and Oracle Financial Consolidation and Close Cloud.,Header for Page 12
12,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud Components,This figure illustrates the Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud components.,Header for Page 12
12,,Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems,Header for Page 12

12,Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems,"Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud enables you to perform accounting transformations on external, non-Oracle source system data. It utilizes the same subledger accounting rules engine that is also used to flexibly create accounting for Oracle subledgers such as Payables and Receivables. Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud includes:",Header for Page 12

12,Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems,"Registration of your external source systems, indicating what types of transactions or activities require accounting from those source systems.",Header for Page 12
12,Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud for External Source Systems,4,Header for Page 12
13,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 13
13,,Chapter 1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Header for Page 13
13,,Create a library of transaction and reference information that is used for defining accounting treatments.,Header for Page 13
13,,Configurable accounting rules to define accounting treatments for transactions.,Header for Page 13

13,,Accounting rules engine that combines transaction and reference information from source systems with accounting rules to create detailed journals stored in an accounting repository.,Header for Page 13
13,,Detailed subledger accounting journal entry repository to enable audit and accounting reconciliation of balances.,Header for Page 13
13,,Reports and user interface inquiries for analyzing accounting transformations.,Header for Page 13
13,,Configurable analytical balances based upon source system or reference attributes.,Header for Page 13
13,,Oracle General Ledger,Header for Page 13

13,Oracle General Ledger,The Oracle General Ledger combines traditional general ledger functionality with embedded Oracle Hyperion Essbase functionality. The general ledger functionality includes:,Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,"Journal entry creation, including updating of account balances cubes and tables.",Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,"Date effective trees for chart of accounts maintenance and financial reporting, including What If analysis.",Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,"Automatic balances cube creation from the chart of accounts configuration, simplifying implementation.",Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,Preaggregated balances at every summarization level across each dimension of the chart of accounts and accounting periods to improve reporting performance.,Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,"Multidimensional analysis using dimensions, such as the chart of accounts, periods, and currency, to provide drill down and drill through functionally.",Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,Drill to details and source ledger balances from summary balances.,Header for Page 13

13,Oracle General Ledger,"Intelligence and analytics embedded within the context of a journal entry, enabling quick and accurate completion of the journal entry process. As journal entries are entered, a What If analysis to determine the impact of the unposted journals on account balances is displayed in the user interface. The What If analysis eliminates navigating to an inquiry page or running a report to verify the results.",Header for Page 13
13,Oracle General Ledger,Three balancing segments available in your chart of accounts for more detailed reporting.,Header for Page 13

13,Oracle General Ledger,"Automatic intercompany balancing journal creation in both Subledger Accounting and General Ledger applications, ensuring proper recording of transactions across legal entities.",Header for Page 13

13,Oracle General Ledger,Calculation Manager rules using complex formulas to distribute revenue and costs throughout the organization for consistent periodic generation of allocation journal entries.,Header for Page 13
13,,Financial Reporting Center,Header for Page 13

13,Financial Reporting Center,The Oracle General Ledger provides a Financial Reporting Center with robust financial reporting and analysis using data from your balances cubes. The dimensions contained in your chart of account segments become the direct source of multidimensional analysis. Direct links are maintained to your transactional data permitting comprehensive drill-down from journals to transaction details. Use the following tools for your reporting and analysis:,Header for Page 13
13,Financial Reporting Center,Financial Reporting to generate your reports.,Header for Page 13
13,Financial Reporting Center,Smart View to generate spreadsheet reports.,Header for Page 13
13,Financial Reporting Center,Oracle Transaction Business Intelligence to report using embedded analytics,Header for Page 13
13,Financial Reporting Center,General Accounting and Journals dashboards to perform online inquiry and dashboard publication,Header for Page 13
13,Financial Reporting Center,Account Monitor and Account Inspector to perform online multidimensional analysis of accounting balances,Header for Page 13

13,Financial Reporting Center,Accounting Hub fits into Oracle's broader enterprise performance management framework through integration with Oracle Planning and Budgeting Cloud and Oracle Financial Consolidation and Close Cloud. You can you can write,Header for Page 13
13,Financial Reporting Center,5,Header for Page 13
14,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 14
14,,Chapter 1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Header for Page 14

14,,budget from Planning and Budgeting Cloud to General Ledger or write the actual data from General Ledger to Planning and Budgeting Cloud. You can use the regular interface to load data from ERP to Financial Consolidation and Close Cloud.,Header for Page 14
14,,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,"Use the Setup and Maintenance work area in Oracle Applications to manage the configuration of legal entities, ledgers, and reporting currencies. To create a legal entity or ledger, first create an implementation project.",Header for Page 14
14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,This implementation project can be populated by either adding a financials-related offering or one or more task lists.,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,Note: Setup tasks that are not related to the ledger or legal entity setup tasks are opened from either an implementation project or directly from the Setup and Maintenance work area.,Header for Page 14
14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,The financial applications have two predefined implementations:,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud offering is used to add the General Ledger and Subledger Accounting application features to an existing Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) source system to enhance reporting and analysis.,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,The Financials offering includes the General Ledger and Subledger Accounting application features and one or more subledger financial applications.,Header for Page 14
14,Overview of Accounting Configuration Offerings,"When adding an offering to an implementation project, update the tasks displayed by adding additional tasks.",Header for Page 14
14,,Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud has two possible implementation scenarios that can be used separately or in conjunction with each other. These scenarios are:,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Accounting for diverse business system events and transactions with configurable and auditable rule-based accounting transformations.,Header for Page 14

14,Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,"Expansion of financial reporting enabling creation of multidimensional, self-service reporting and analytics with real-time accounting information from a single source with flexible formatting options.",Header for Page 14
14,Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,This figure illustrates Accounting Hub implementation scenarios.,Header for Page 14
14,Overview of Implementation Options for Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,6,Header for Page 14
15,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 15
15,,Chapter 1 Introduction to Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud,Header for Page 15
15,,Accounting for Diverse Transactions,Header for Page 15

15,Accounting for Diverse Transactions,The Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud provides accounting for diverse business system events and transactions using configurable and auditable rule-based accounting transformations. The Accounting Hub process:,Header for Page 15
15,Accounting for Diverse Transactions,"Begins with transactions and data from your non-Oracle, industry-specific subledgers and other general ledgers.",Header for Page 15

15,Accounting for Diverse Transactions,Generates accounting events using the Create Accounting process to create journals that can be posted to the Oracle General Ledger from specific subledgers and other general ledgers.,Header for Page 15
15,Accounting for Diverse Transactions,Ends with complete reporting and analysis solutions.,Header for Page 15

15,Accounting for Diverse Transactions,See the following for details on implementing this scenario: Define Accounting Transformation chapter in the Oracle Financials Cloud Implementing Accounting Hub guide.,Header for Page 15
15,,Expansion of Financial Reporting,Header for Page 15

15,Expansion of Financial Reporting,"Oracle Accounting Hub Cloud enables creation of multidimensional, self-service reporting and analytics with real time accounting information from a single source with flexible formatting options. The Financial Reporting Center includes:",Header for Page 15
15,Expansion of Financial Reporting,Predefined financial reports,Header for Page 15
15,Expansion of Financial Reporting,"Ability to create reports,",Header for Page 15
15,Expansion of Financial Reporting,Flexible options for dissemination of such reports,Header for Page 15
15,Expansion of Financial Reporting,7,Header for Page 15

instance. This could result in some redundant
folders. In this case, you can reorganize child
folders in the structure on the target instance
and delete any unneeded folders.

20,Overview of Implementing Financials,"To start your Financials implementation, use the Setup and Maintenance work area to opt into the offerings that meet your business requirements. Refer to the Oracle Applications Cloud Using Functional Setup Manager guide to manage the opt-in and setup of your offerings.",Header for Page 20
20,Overview of Implementing Financials,Financials Offering,Header for Page 20
20,Overview of Implementing Financials
column2: Financials Offering,"By using the Financials offering, you can configure how you manage financial flows, including assets, ledgers, cash cycle, invoices and payments, accounts receivable, collections, and the setup of subledger accounting and tax configuration.",Header for Page 20

column1: 20,Overview of Implementing Financials
column2: Financials Offering,"The following table specifies the primary functional areas of this offering. For the full list of functional areas and features in this offering, use the Associated Features report that you review when you plan the implementation of your offering.",Header for Page 20

column1: 20,Overview of Implementing Financials
21,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 21
Bill Management
column2: Manage system options and user registrations.

column1: Budgetary Control and Encumbrance
Accounting
column2: Manage control budgets and encumbrance accounting, along with data access for users. Public sector

column1: customers typically use this functional area.
Cash Management and Banking
column2: Manage banks, bank branches, and bank accounts. Additionally, define reconciliation matching rules,

column1: bank statement transaction creation rules, parse rules, transaction codes, and transaction type
mapping. Furthermore, configure your cash positioning and cash forecasting options.
Collections
column2: Manage aging methods and collectors, as well as collections preferences, scoring data points, and

column1: strategy tasks.
Customer Billing
column2: Manage Receivables transactions and customer billing: AutoInvoice, payment terms, transaction types,

column1: transaction sources, memo lines, balance forward billing, and recurring billing.
Customer Payments
column2: Manage Receivables customer payments and receipts: receipt classes and methods, AutoCash rules,

column1: Application rules, AutoMatch, Lockbox.
Expenses
column2: Manage expense report templates, approval rules, and conversion rates and policies. If applicable, opt

column1: into using corporate cards for expenses, processing of expense receipt imaging, or integration with
travel.
Financial Reporting Center
column2: Manage the financial tools to report and analyze accounting data: Financial Reporting Center, Smart

column1: View, Financial Reporting Studio, and Workspace.
Fixed Assets
column2: Manage asset locations, calendars, books and categories, along with depreciation methods.

column1: General Ledger
column2: Manage ledgers, accounting configurations, journal sources and categories, and other related

column1: accounting setup. If applicable, opt into configuring journal approval email notifications.
Intercompany
column2: Manage Intercompany transaction processing within Financials, intercompany balancing and

column1: reconciliation.
Joint Venture Management
column2: Manage the distribution of joint venture revenue and costs among joint venture partners while

column1: preserving essential data for tracking and auditing.
Payables
column2: Manage supplier invoice and payment options, payment terms, distribution sets, invoice tolerances,

column1: and procurement agents.
Payments
column2: Manage payment systems, payment methods, formats, and payment process profiles. If applicable, opt

column1: into deriving a bank account number from IBAN.
Receivables
column2: Manage the required setups to enable Receivables for transactions and receipts: Receivables system

column1: options; Receivables activities; AutoAccounting rules; remit-to addresses; and statement cycles.
Revenue Management
column2: Manage system options for revenue management, selling price profiles, hierarchies, resources, and

column1: Trading Community source systems."

24,Overview of Initial Configuration with the Enterprise Structures Configurator,The Enterprise Structures Configurator is an interview-based tool that guides you through the process of setting up a basic enterprise structure.,Header for Page 24

24,Overview of Initial Configuration with the Enterprise Structures Configurator,"By answering questions about your enterprise, the tool creates a structure of divisions, legal entities, business units, and reference data sets that reflects your enterprise structure. After you create your enterprise structure, you also follow a guided process to determine whether to use positions, and whether to set up additional attributes for jobs and positions. After you define your enterprise structure and your job and position structures, you can review them, make any necessary changes, and then load the final configuration.",Header for Page 24

24,FAQs for Define Initial Configuration
column2: What happens if I don't use the Enterprise Structures Configurator to set up my enterprise structures?,"The Enterprise Structures Configurator is an interview-based tool that guides you through setting up divisions, legal entities, business units, and reference data sets.",Header for Page 24

column1: 24,FAQs for Define Initial Configuration
column2: What happens if I don't use the Enterprise Structures Configurator to set up my enterprise structures?,"If you don't use the Enterprise Structures Configurator, then you must set up your enterprise structure using the individual tasks that correspond to each enterprise component. In addition, you can't set up multiple configurations and compare different scenarios. Using the Enterprise Structures Configurator is the recommended process for setting up your enterprise structures.",Header for Page 24

25,What's an ultimate holding company?,"The legal entity that represents the top level in your organization hierarchy, as defined by the legal name entered for the enterprise. This designation is used only to create an organization tree, with these levels:",Header for Page 25

25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub,Define Enterprises,Header for Page 25
25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub
column2: Define Enterprises,An enterprise is a collection of legal entities sharing common control and management.,Header for Page 25

column1: 25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub
25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub
column3: Enterprise Defined,"When implementing Oracle Fusion Cloud Applications you operate within the context of an enterprise that has already been created in the application for you. This is either a predefined enterprise or an enterprise that has been created in the application by a system administrator. An enterprise organization captures the name of the deploying enterprise and the location of the headquarters. In Oracle Fusion Applications, an organization classified as an enterprise is defined before defining any other organizations in the HCM Common Organization Model. All other organizations are defined as belonging to an enterprise.",Header for Page 25

column1: 25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub,Enterprise Information for Non-HCM Users,Header for Page 25
25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub
column3: Enterprise Defined,"The Manage Enterprise HCM Information task includes default settings for your enterprise such as the employment model, worker number generation, and so on.",Header for Page 25

column1: 25,Enterprise for Oracle Accounting Hub
column3: Enterprise Defined,"If you're not implementing Oracle Fusion Human Capital Management (HCM), then the only action you may need to perform using this task is to change the enterprise name, if necessary. The other settings are HCM-specific and aren't relevant outside of Oracle Fusion HCM.",Header for Page 25

column1: 25,,Overview of Legal Jurisdictions and Authorities,Header for Page 25
25,Overview of Legal Jurisdictions and Authorities
column3: Enterprise Defined,You are required to register your legal entities with legal authorities in the jurisdictions where you conduct business. Register your legal entities as required by local business requirements or other relevant laws.,Header for Page 25

column1: 25,Overview of Legal Jurisdictions and Authorities
column3: Enterprise Defined,"For example, register your legal entities for tax reporting to report sales taxes or value added taxes.",Header for Page 25

26,Overview of Geographies,Setting up your geography structure and master geographies correctly in the Trading Community Model is critical to the proper use and management of Oracle Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Cloud applications.,Header for Page 26

26,Overview of Geographies,"The geography structure and master geography data is shared across multiple product families and applications. Address validation ensures complete and valid master address data across all location entities across product applications. In addition, complete and valid master data is critical for accurate transaction tax calculation.",Header for Page 26
26,Overview of Geographies,You can either define your geography structure and corresponding master geographies manually or import these geography entities. You can use the:,Header for Page 26

26,Overview of Geographies,"1. Manage Geographies page 2. Import Management process For more information about managing your geographies, see the Geographies section in the Define Enterprise Structures chapter in the Oracle ERP Cloud Implementing Common Features for Financials and Project Management guide on Oracle Help Center (https://docs.oracle.com).",Header for Page 26

column2: Manage Geographies,"Use the Manage Geographies page to manually define your geography structure, hierarchy, mapping, and validation. 29,3 Financial Reporting Structures
column2: Overview of Financial Reporting Structure,Define your enterprise structures in your chart of accounts to track and report on your financial objectives and meet your reporting requirements.,Header for Page 29

column1: 29,3 Financial Reporting Structures
column2: Overview of Financial Reporting Structure,The benefit of representing your enterprise in the chart of accounts is the functionality which includes multidimensional reporting with its Essbase tool. Segments included in the chart of accounts become dimensions in Essbase. The recorded data is automatically loaded into the Essbase cube when you post your journal entries. The Essbase tool includes powerful functionality for analysis and reporting on your financial data.,Header for Page 29

column1: 29,3 Financial Reporting Structures
column3: Overview of Chart of Accounts,"The chart of accounts is the underlying structure for organizing financial information and reporting. An entity records transactions with a set of codes representing balances by type, expenses by function, and other divisional or organizational codes that are important to its business.",Header for Page 29

column1: 29,3 Financial Reporting Structures
column3: Overview of Chart of Accounts,"The chart of accounts facilitates aggregating data from different operations, from within an operation, and from different business flows, thus enabling the organization to report using consistent definitions to their stakeholders in compliance with legislative and corporate reporting standards and aiding in management decisions.",Header for Page 29

column3: Chart of Accounts Structures and Instances,"In Oracle Fusion General Ledger, the chart of accounts model is framed around the concept of a chart of accounts structure, under which one or more chart of accounts structure instances can be created.",Header for Page 29

30,Chart of Accounts Structure,"When creating the segments for the chart of accounts structure, you must enter segment sequence numbers that are consecutive and begin with the number one.",Header for Page 30
30,,Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,Header for Page 30

30,Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,"For segments in your chart of account structure instance that you expect to contain a large number of distinct values, you must perform the following steps:",Header for Page 30

30,Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,"In the chart of accounts definition, mark the segment query required option as selectively required . To perform searches in the transactional user interface, you have to specify the following segment as a mandatory search criteria .",Header for Page 30
30,Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,Create required indexes in the GL_CODE_COMBINATIONS table for segments that are selectively required.,Header for Page 30

30,Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,"CAUTION: For the Accounting Key Flexfield value sets used in your chart of accounts structure and instance, you must use independent validation only. If you use other validations, you may not be able to use the full chart of accounts functionality, such as data security, reporting, and account hierarchy integration.",Header for Page 30
30,,Overview of Creating and Configuring Chart of Accounts Structure and Instances,Header for Page 30
30,Overview of Creating and Configuring Chart of Accounts Structure and Instances
column2: Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,"In Oracle General Ledger, the chart of accounts model is framed around the concept of a chart of accounts structure, for which one or more chart of accounts structure instances can be created.",Header for Page 30

column1: 30,Overview of Creating and Configuring Chart of Accounts Structure and Instances
column2: Chart of Accounts Structure Instance,"A chart of accounts structure defines the key attributes for your chart of accounts. These attributes include the number of segments, the segment sequences, the segment names, segment prompts, segment labels, for example natural account and primary balancing, and default value sets.",Header for Page 30

31,,All segments of the chart of accounts are required and have to be enabled. The unused segments can be assigned value sets that have a single value in the chart of accounts structure instance. The value is set as a default for that segment so that the extra segments are automatically populated when an account account combination is used.,Header for Page 31
31,,Overview of Value Sets,Header for Page 31
31,Overview of Value Sets,A value set is a group of valid values that you assign to a flexfield segment to control the values that are stored for business object attributes.,Header for Page 31

31,Overview of Value Sets,A user enters a value for an attribute of a business object while using the application. The flexfield validates the value against the set of valid values that you configured as a value set and assigned to the segment.,Header for Page 31

31,,Account Hierarchies,Header for Page 31
31,Account Hierarchies,Overview of Trees,Header for Page 31
31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,"Trees are hierarchical data models that you can use to organize data, apply business rules, control data access, and improve performance while querying.",Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,"For example, an application maintains data of an organization called Vision Corporation that has two departments: Marketing and Finance. The Finance department has two functional divisions: Receivables and Payables. You can define a tree for Vision Corporation to establish a hierarchy across its departments, and their respective functional divisions. You can use the hierarchy to manage data at various levels of the organization.",Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,"To work with trees, in the Setup and Maintenance work area, use any of the following tasks:",Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,Manage Tree Structures: To create and update tree structures. You must first define a tree structure to create a tree.,Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,Manage Trees and Tree Versions: To create and update trees and their versions.,Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,Manage Tree Labels: To create and update tree labels.,Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column2: Overview of Trees,Tree Structures,Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
column3: Tree Structures,"As the name suggests, tree structures provide you the framework to organize data such that you can establish a hierarchy for use by the tree. So, similar to a template, a tree structure guides the creation of a tree.",Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
31,Account Hierarchies
column3: Tree,"A tree is an instance of the tree structure. The root node is the highest nodal point of a tree. Child nodes branch off from the root node. Child nodes at the same level, branching off from a common parent node, are called siblings. Leaves are",Header for Page 31

column1: 31,Account Hierarchies
32,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 32
32,,Chapter 3 Financial Reporting Structures,Header for Page 32
32,,details branching off from a node but not extending further down the tree hierarchy. You can create trees for multiple data sources and share them across applications.,Header for Page 32
32,,Tree Versions,Header for Page 32

32,Tree Versions,"A tree by default has only one version. If required, you can create and maintain more than one editable tree version. At any point, only one tree version must be active. If you edit an existing version, it changes from active to draft. To use it again, you must set it to active. Similar to any other version control system, versions of trees are maintained to track all the changes that a tree undergoes in its life cycle.",Header for Page 32
32,,Tree Labels,Header for Page 32

32,Tree Labels,"Tree labels are short names given to trees and tree structures. You can label the tree versions for better accessibility and information retrieval. When nodes are created in a tree, the existing tree labels are automatically assigned to the new tree nodes. You can use any table to store the labels and register the label data source with the tree structure.",Header for Page 32
32,Tree Labels,Related Topics,Header for Page 32
32,Tree Labels,Tree Labels,Header for Page 32
32,Tree Labels,Tree Structures,Header for Page 32
32,,Overview of Managing Account Hierarchies,Header for Page 32
32,Overview of Managing Account Hierarchies
column2: Tree Labels,Account hierarchies are defined in Oracle Fusion applications using tree functionality. Each account hierarchy is defined as a tree with one or more versions. Tree versions are used to track account hierarchies as they change over time.,Header for Page 32

column1: 32,Overview of Managing Account Hierarchies
column2: Tree Labels,"For example, an account hierarchy to summarize cost of goods has different accounts for 2011, versus 2010. The changes are in the business operations and affect the chart of accounts values.",Header for Page 32

column1: 32,Overview of Managing Account Hierarchies
column2: Tree Labels,"Chart of accounts values can be associated with multiple hierarchies by defining multiple trees. Using multiple trees enable create financial reports for different target audiences. For example, you can use different hierarchies to track cost centers either by geography or line of business.",Header for Page 32

column1: 32,Overview of Managing Account Hierarchies
column2: Tree Labels,"Before setting up hierarchies, you may want to consider different hierarchy requirements for financial reporting, allocations, cross validation rules, revaluations, and chart of accounts mapping.",Header for Page 32

33,Overview of Maintaining Account Hierarchies,"This topic describes the best practices of maintaining and publishing the account hierarchies. Account hierarchies are used throughout Oracle Fusion General Ledger for creating financial reports, Smart View inquiries, allocation definitions, cross validation rules, and revaluation definitions.",Header for Page 33

33,Overview of Maintaining Account Hierarchies,Account Hierarchy Trees,Header for Page 33

33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: How can I manage and review account hierarchies?,"View segment value descriptions when creating, editing, or reviewing account hierarchies online. You can also export account hierarchies to a spreadsheet to review, analyze, and report offline.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: How can I manage and review account hierarchies?,"To export all nodes in the hierarchies to a spreadsheet, expand all nodes first from View -> Expand All in the Manage Account Hierarchies: Specify Nodes page.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies,When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,Header for Page 33
33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,Row Flattening and Column Flattening for tree versions must be manually submitted in the following scenarios.,Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,A new tree or tree version is defined,Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,"If the tree or tree version has any change made to it that would alter the flattened hierarchy data. For example, adding, moving, and duplicating members. Basically, anything that impacts the flattened hierarchy data.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,"If Data Relationship Management (DRM) is used with Oracle General Ledger, after running the Load Account Values and Hierarchies process from the Scheduled Process work area to load chart of accounts reference data from DRM to General Ledger.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,"When range based hierarchy assignments are supported, if new values are added that are within the account range assigned to the hierarchy.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,"Note: In this case, try submitting the flattening programs using the Online Mode first. If the newly inserted child account value does not appear to be included in the flattened hierarchy data, then the flattening program has to be submitted using the Force Flattening Mode , instead of Online Flattening . An issue with the incremental flattening programs can prevent them from picking up this type of hierarchy change, so full flattening can be required.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,"Note: Column flattening processed data is primarily relevant to Oracle Fusion Transactional Business Intelligence, but there should not be any adverse impact to run both row and column flattening processes.",Header for Page 33

column1: 33,FAQs for Manage Account Hierarchies
column2: When do I manually submit row and column flattening for tree versions?,25,Header for Page 33

column1: 34,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 34
Level
column2: Labels that are automatically assigned based on the data source to which the tree node belongs.

column1: A level label points to a specific data source. For example, in a tree that reflects the organizational
hierarchy of an enterprise, all division nodes appear on one level and all department nodes on another.
Group
column2: Labels that you can arbitrarily assign to tree nodes.

column1: Depth
column2: Labels that are automatically assigned based on the depth of the tree node within the tree. No manual

column1: assignment is performed.
Note:
In an unbalanced hierarchy, a level may not be equal to depth."
34,,Chapter 3 Financial Reporting Structures,Header for Page 34
34,,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,Header for Page 34

34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,"A tree structure defines the hierarchy for creating trees and prescribes rules based on which trees are created, versioned, and accessed. You can associate multiple data sources with a tree structure.",Header for Page 34
34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,A tree is an instance of this hierarchy. Every tree structure can contain one or more trees.,Header for Page 34

34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,"You can create tree structures specific to an application but you can share tree structures across applications. If you apply version control to the tree structure, it's carried over to the trees that are based on the tree structure. Each tree version contains at least one root node. Occasionally, a tree version may have more than one root node.",Header for Page 34
34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,An administrator controls the access to tree structures through a set of rules that are periodically audited for validity.,Header for Page 34
34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,Related Topics,Header for Page 34
34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,Guidelines for Defining the Tree Structure,Header for Page 34

34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,Guidelines for Specifying Data Sources for Tree Structures,Header for Page 34
34,Overview of Managing Tree Structures,Guidelines for Improving the Performance of a Tree Structure,Header for Page 34
34,,Tree Labels,Header for Page 34
34,Tree Labels,Tree labels are tags that are stored on tree nodes. You can store labels in any table and register the label data source with the tree structure.,Header for Page 34

34,Tree Labels,"When a labeling scheme is used for trees, the selected labels are stored in the tree label entity, and each tree node contains a reference to a tree label in the labeling scheme. The following table lists the three ways in which tree labels are assigned to the tree nodes.",Header for Page 34

35,Overview of Managing Tree Versions,"You can create and edit trees and tree versions depending upon the requirement. A tree can have one or more tree versions. When you change an existing tree, a new version is created and published.",Header for Page 35

35,Segment Value Attributes
column2: Segment Labels,Segment labels identify certain segments in your chart of accounts structure and assign special functionality to those segments. Best practice is to assign each segment label one time within the chart of accounts structure.,Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes
column2: Segment Labels,Here are the segment labels that are available to use with the chart of accounts.,Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes
column2: Segment Labels,"CAUTION: Validations aren't performed when segment labels are assigned, so verify that all are assigned correctly before using your chart of accounts.",Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes
35,Segment Value Attributes
column3: Balancing,"Ensures that all journals balance for each balancing segment value or combination of multiple balancing segment values. You can secure access to your primary balancing segment values only with data access sets. The General Ledger application automatically calculates and creates balancing lines as required in journal entries. For example, recognizing an entity's receivable and the other entity's payable. The three balancing segment labels are primary, second, and third balancing. The primary balancing segment label is required.",Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes
35,Segment Value Attributes
column3: Cost Center,"Represents the smallest segment of an organization for which costs are collected and reported. Facilitates grouping of natural accounts by functional cost types, accommodating tracking of specific business expenses across natural accounts. As cost centers combine expenses and headcount data into costs, they're useful for detailed analysis and reporting. Cost centers are optional, but required for:",Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes
column3: Cost Center,"Tracking depreciation, additions, and other transactions in Oracle Fusion Assets.",Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes
column3: Cost Center,Storing expense approval limits in Oracle Fusion Expense.,Header for Page 35

column1: 35,Segment Value Attributes

36,,Chapter 3 Financial Reporting Structures,Header for Page 36
36,,Natural Account,Header for Page 36

36,Natural Account,"Determines the account type (asset, liability, expense, revenue, or equity), whether posting is allowed, and other information specific to the segment value. The natural account segment is mapped to the Financial Category dimension in the balances cube to enable ad hoc reporting and transactional dashboards. This functionality uses Oracle Fusion Business Intelligence Enterprise Edition to analyze and drill into expense and revenue transactions. The natural account segment label is required.",Header for Page 36
36,,Intercompany,Header for Page 36

36,Intercompany,"Optionally, assign the segment to be used in intercompany balancing functionality. You can't use the primary balancing or natural account segments as the intercompany segment. You can assign the same values to both the primary balancing and intercompany value sets. You can also assign the same value set to the primary balancing segment and the intercompany segment. The sharing of the value set or values:",Header for Page 36
36,Intercompany,Enables clear visibility of the due to and due from relationships inherent in intercompany accounting across the entire organization.,Header for Page 36
36,Intercompany,Saves maintenance and ensure completeness.,Header for Page 36

36,Intercompany,"However, sharing value sets can cause problems when applying segment value security rules because the rules applied to both segments. The rules can restrict access to certain values which may complicate entering intercompany entries. For example, you might have access to company 01 at the balancing segment level but not company 02. As a result, you can't enter an intercompany entry for transactions between 01 and 02.",Header for Page 36
36,Intercompany,Related Topics,Header for Page 36

36,,Example of Segment Labels,Header for Page 36
36,Example of Segment Labels
column2: Intercompany,"For a chart of accounts, each segment can be qualified by a label to distinctly indicate its purpose. The label designation is used by Oracle Fusion General Ledger processes to determine how to display and process transactions and balances that are recorded.",Header for Page 36

column1: 36,Example of Segment Labels,Scenario,Header for Page 36
36,Example of Segment Labels
column2: Scenario,"You are creating your chart of accounts with six segments. General Ledger permits selection of up to 30 segments for your chart of accounts. You must have a minimum of three required segments, as determined by the number of required segment labels (qualifiers). Required segment labels are:",Header for Page 36

column1: 36,Example of Segment Labels
column2: Scenario,Primary Balancing Segment: Main balancing segment typically used to represent the company dimension of the organization. The segment set with this label can't be set with another label.,Header for Page 36

column1: 36,Example of Segment Labels
column2: Scenario,Cost Center Segment: Smallest segment of an organization for which you collect and report costs. You are required to create this segment if you're implementing Oracle Fusion Assets.,Header for Page 36

column1: 36,Example of Segment Labels
column2: Scenario,"Natural Account Segment: Classification of transactions and balances according to distinct account types: asset, liability, equity, revenue, and expense accounts. The segment set with this label can't be set with another label.",Header for Page 36

37,,"For Oracle Transactional Business Intelligence reporting, all labeled segments of the chart of accounts are automatically maintained in the data that reporting is based on. The granularity of information stored in the nonqualified segments is summarized and Oracle Transactional Business Intelligence isn't able to provide detailed reporting by segments. To maintain the ability to perform detailed reporting on such segments, create user-defined labels to qualify these segments.",Header for Page 37

37,,"For example, one of the segments of the chart of accounts is based on product line, and none of the segment labels are applicable. The organization must derive product line-based Oracle Transactional Business Intelligence reports. Create a user-defined label called Product Line to use to qualify the Product Line segment of the chart of accounts.",Header for Page 37

38,,Overview of Balancing Segments,Header for Page 38

38,Overview of Balancing Segments,Balancing segments ensure that all journals balance for each balancing segment value or combination of multiple balancing segment values. You can secure access to your primary balancing segment values only with data access sets.,Header for Page 38

38,Overview of Balancing Segments,"The General Ledger application automatically calculates and creates balancing lines as required in journal entries. By enabling multiple balancing segments for your chart of accounts, you can produce financial statements for each unique combination of segment values across one, two, or three qualified balancing segments. This ability provides you greater insights into your operations as it affords you visibility along the critical fiscal dimensions you use to plan, monitor, and measure your financial performance.",Header for Page 38

38,,Examples of Segment Value Inheritance,Header for Page 38
38,Examples of Segment Value Inheritance,The Inherit Segment Value Attributes process simplifies the chart of accounts maintenance.,Header for Page 38

38,Examples of Segment Value Inheritance,"When the characteristics of values in the value sets are updated, such as changes to enabled status, effective date, posting allowed status, or natural account type, all previously created account combinations that referenced such values aren't automatically updated by these changes. The Inherit Segment Value Attributes process lets you run a controlled process to update such existing account combinations. This process maintains and corrects the current attribute settings for those account combinations that contain the account values that were changed.",Header for Page 38

38,Examples of Segment Value Inheritance,"For account combinations where the present settings must be retained and not impacted by account attribute changes, activate the option to preserve the account combination's attributes. The Preserve Attributes option can be found on the Manage Account Combinations page. Activating the option prevents those account combination's attributes from being updated when the Inherit Segment Value Attributes process is run.",Header for Page 38

column2: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?,"The chart of accounts structure and structure instance are fundamental constructs in General Ledger accounting setup and can't be altered once they're used. The number of segments, the segments' order, each segment's label, length, type, and value set assignment can't be updated.",Header for Page 39

column1: 39,FAQs for Maintain Segment Values Attributes
column2: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?,These components set the foundation upon which accounting data is recorded for ledgers that use them. Careful and thoughtful planning must precede all decisions pertaining to defining the chart of accounts.,Header for Page 39

39,Overview of Deploying Flexfield
column2: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?,Deployment generates or refreshes the Application Development Framework (ADF) business component objects that render the flexfield in a user interface. The deployment process adds user-defined attributes to the Web Services Description Language (WSDL) schemas exposed by Oracle ADF services and used by SOA composites.,Header for Page 39

column1: 39,Overview of Deploying Flexfield
column2: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?,"Flexfields are deployed for the first time during the application provisioning process. After you configure or change a flexfield, you must deploy it to make the latest definition available to users.",Header for Page 39

column1: 39,Overview of Deploying Flexfield
column2: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?,"If a descriptive flexfield is enabled for business intelligence, the deployment process redeploys the flexfield's business intelligence artifacts.",Header for Page 39

column1: 39,Overview of Deploying Flexfield
column2: How can I change segments in an existing chart of accounts structure?,You can deploy a flexfield to a sandbox for testing or to the mainline metadata for use in a test or production run time environment. You can deploy extensible flexfields as a background process.,Header for Page 39

41,,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping,Header for Page 41

41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping,The chart of accounts mapping feature supports the ability to correlate a source chart of accounts to a target chart of accounts to allow for the processing of balances or amounts.,Header for Page 41

41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping,"Use either segment rules, account rules, or a combination of both. A chart of accounts mapping is used by the posting process in propagating transactions from the primary ledger to its secondary ledger. The mapping feature is used by both balance transfer processes for balance level secondary ledgers as well as cross ledger transfers. The balances are copied from one ledger to another ledger in both processes.",Header for Page 41

41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping,"You can define chart of accounts mappings using the Manage Chart of Accounts Mapping task. If youre defining mappings that include only segment rules, you can also use the Chart of Accounts Mapping Rules Import file-based data import (FBDI).",Header for Page 41
41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping,Segment Rules,Header for Page 41
41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: Segment Rules,"Use segment rules to map each segment of the target chart of accounts to an account value, or to one or two segments in the source chart of accounts. You can select from among three different mapping methods:",Header for Page 41

column1: 41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: Segment Rules,Assign a constant value for a segment in the target chart of accounts.,Header for Page 41

column1: 41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: Segment Rules,Copy the value from the source segment to the corresponding target segment.,Header for Page 41

column1: 41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: Segment Rules,"Note: To use this method, the value sets for the paired target and source segments must share identical values.",Header for Page 41

column1: 41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: Segment Rules,Use rollup rules to aggregate one or two source segments to a corresponding target segment.,Header for Page 41

column1: 41,Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: Segment Rules,"Create a single value mapping when a specific detail source segment value is given a detail target segment value. Use hierarchical rollup rules when a specific parent source value and all of its child segment values are mapped to a given detail target segment value. This provides the ability to process groups of source segment values in one single rollup rule. Define parent source values in rollup rules when date effective versions of the hierarchy are used with the accounting date of the transactions by the processes that reference the chart of accounts mapping. The additional benefit of self-maintaining mappings is that if the hierarchies referenced change with time, the applicable child values are updated automatically.",Header for Page 41

column1: 41,"Segment Rules and Account Rules for Chart of Accounts Mapping
column3: Create a single value mapping when a specific detail source segment value is given a detail target segment value. Use hierarchical rollup rules when a specific parent source value and all of its child segment values are mapped to a given detail target segment value. This provides the ability to process groups of source segment values in one single rollup rule. Define parent source values in rollup rules when date effective versions of the hierarchy are used with the accounting date of the transactions by the processes that reference the chart of accounts mapping. The additional benefit of self-maintaining mappings is that if the hierarchies referenced change with time, the applicable child values are updated automatically.",33,Header for Page 41

column2: What's the difference between mapping with segment rules and mapping with account rules?
column3: Account Rules,Note: Segment and account rules can be used alone or both types of mapping rules can be used in the same mapping set.,Header for Page 42

column1: 42,FAQ for Manage Chart of Accounts Mapping,When do account rules override segment rules in a chart of accounts mapping?,Header for Page 42
42,FAQ for Manage Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: When do account rules override segment rules in a chart of accounts mapping?
column3: Account Rules,"You can create a chart of accounts mapping using only segment rules, only account rules, or a combination of both segment and account rules. If an overlap exists between the two types of rule, the account rule supersedes.",Header for Page 42

column1: 42,FAQ for Manage Chart of Accounts Mapping
column2: When do account rules override segment rules in a chart of accounts mapping?
column3: Account Rules,Segment rules are used to broadly define the relationship between two charts of accounts on a segment by segment basis. Account rules can be used to more precisely map specific source account combinations to their target accounts.,Header for Page 42

column3: Account Rules,Define an accounting calendar to create your accounting year and the periods it contains. Specify common calendar options that the application uses to automatically generate a calendar with its periods.,Header for Page 42

43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: How can I identify errors in my accounting calendar?,Erroneous entries are identified online as you enter a new calendar or change data on an existing calendar. The application also automatically validates the data when you save the calendar.,Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars,What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,Header for Page 43
43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,The period naming format determines the year that's appended to the prefix for each period in the calendar.,Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,"For the example, your accounting year has a set of twelve accounting period with:",Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,"Start date of September 1, 2014.",Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,"End date is August 31, 2015.",Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,Period's date range following the natural calendar month date range.,Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,"Calendar period naming format: Select the calendar period format to append the period's start date's year to the prefix. For the period covering September 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014, then 2014 or just 14, depending on the period format selected, is appended to each period's name. For the remaining periods covering January 1, 2015 to August 31, 2015, then 2015 or 15, is appended to each period's name.",Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: What's the difference between calendar and fiscal period naming?,"Fiscal period naming format: Select the fiscal period format to always append the period's year assignment to the prefix. If the accounting periods in the set of twelve are all assigned the year of 2015, then 2015 or just 15, depending on the period format selected, is appended to the period name of all 12 periods.",Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars,When do I update an existing calendar?,Header for Page 43
43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: When do I update an existing calendar?,"Update an existing calendar before the new periods are needed as future periods, based on the future period setting in your accounting configuration.",Header for Page 43

column1: 43,FAQs for Define Calendars
column2: When do I update an existing calendar?,"If a complete year has been defined and validated, use the Add Year button to add the next year quickly. Accept or change the new rows as required. For example, with the Other frequency type calendar, dates may differ from what the application generates.",Header for Page 43

44,,What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?,Header for Page 44
44,,What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?,Header for Page 44

44,What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?,The migration script assigns a period frequency that most closely matches your Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12 calendar.,Header for Page 44

44,What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?,"When you use the Oracle Fusion Cloud Applications Add Year functionality for the first time, you have an opportunity to review and change the period frequency. The Calendar Options page opens only for calendars upgraded from Release 12 to allow a one time modification.",Header for Page 44

44,What happens if I upgrade my calendar from Oracle E-Business Suite Release 12?,"Make your changes to the period frequency, adjusting period frequency, and period name format, including the prefix and separator, as needed. Changes cannot conflict with the existing upgraded calendar definition. Update the calendar name and description in the calendar header, as needed, for all calendars. Period details for a new year are generated automatically based on the latest calendar options. You can also manually update the calendar. The modified calendar options affect future years only.",Header for Page 44

45,,Euro Currency Derivation,Header for Page 45

45,Euro Currency Derivation,"Use the Derivation Type, Derivation Factor, and Derivation Effective Date fields to define the relationship between the official currency (Euro) of the European Monetary Union (EMU) and the national currencies of EMU member states.",Header for Page 45

45,Euro Currency Derivation,"For each EMU currency, you define its Euro-to-EMU fixed conversion rate and the effective starting date. If you have to use a different currency for Euro, you can disable the predefined currency and create a new one.",Header for Page 45
45,Euro Currency Derivation,Derivation Type,Header for Page 45
45,Euro Currency Derivation
column2: Derivation Type,"The Euro currency derivation type is used only for the Euro, and the Euro derived derivation type identifies national currencies of EMU member states. All other currencies don't have derivation types.",Header for Page 45

column1: 45,Euro Currency Derivation,Derivation Factor,Header for Page 45
45,Euro Currency Derivation
column2: Derivation Factor,The derivation factor is the fixed conversion rate by which you multiply one Euro to derive the equivalent EMU currency amount. The Euro currency itself must not have a derivation factor.,Header for Page 45

column1: 45,Euro Currency Derivation,Derivation Effective Date,Header for Page 45
45,Euro Currency Derivation
column2: Derivation Effective Date,The derivation effective date is the date on which the relationship between the EMU currency and the Euro begins.,Header for Page 45

All currencies listed in the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 4217 standard are supported.",Header for Page 45

45,"FAQs for Manage Currencies
column2: What's the difference between precision, extended precision, and minimum accountable unit for a currency?
column3: Derivation Effective Date","Precision refers to the number of digits placed after the decimal point used in regular currency transactions. For example, USD would have 2 as the precision value for transactional amounts, such as $1.00.",Header for Page 45

column1: 45,"FAQs for Manage Currencies
column2: What's the difference between precision, extended precision, and minimum accountable unit for a currency?
column3: Derivation Effective Date","Extended precision is the number of digits placed after the decimal point and must be greater than or equal to the precision value. For calculations requiring greater precision, you can enter an extended precision value such as 3 or 4. That would result in the currency appearing as $1.279 or $1.2793.",Header for Page 45

column1: 45,"FAQs for Manage Currencies

46,,"Minimum accountable unit is the smallest denomination for the currency. For example, for USD that would be .01 for a cent.",Header for Page 46
46,,You can set these values for a currency using the Manage Currencies task in the Application Extensions functional area in the Setup and Maintenance work area.,Header for Page 46
46,,"Note: When setting up currencies, make sure you use the correct precision. Some currencies, for example, the Chilean peso, dont support precision at all.",Header for Page 46

column1: 46,Conversion Rate Types
column2: Guidelines for Creating Conversion Rate Types,"You can use different rate types for different business needs. During journal entry, the conversion rate is provided automatically based on the selected conversion rate type and currency, unless the rate type is User . For User rate types, you must enter a conversion rate. You can define additional rate types as needed. Set your most frequently used rate type as the default. Conversion rate types can't be deleted.",Header for Page 46

column1: 46,Conversion Rate Types
column2: Guidelines for Creating Conversion Rate Types,"Assign conversion rate types to automatically populate the associated rate for your period average and period end rates for the ledger. For example, you can assign the conversion rate type of Spot to populate period average rates, and the conversion rate type of Corporate to populate period end rates. Period average and period end rates are used in translation of account balances.",Header for Page 46

column1: 46,Conversion Rate Types
column2: Guidelines for Creating Conversion Rate Types,Conversion rate types are used to automatically assign a rate when you perform the following accounting functions:,Header for Page 46

47,,Enforce Inverse Relationships,Header for Page 47

47,Enforce Inverse Relationships,The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.,Header for Page 47
47,Enforce Inverse Relationships
column2: The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.,Action Results,Header for Page 47

column1: 47,Enforce Inverse Relationships
column2: The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.,Selected,Header for Page 47

column1: 47,Enforce Inverse Relationships
column2: The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.,"When you enter a daily rate to convert currency A to currency B, the inverse rate of currency B to currency A is automatically calculated and entered in the adjacent column. If either rate is changed, the application automatically recalculates the other rate. You can update the application calculated inverse rate, but once you do, the related rate is updated. The option enforces the inverse relationship is maintained but doesn't prevent you from updating the rates.",Header for Page 47

column1: 47,Enforce Inverse Relationships
column2: The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.,Not Selected,Header for Page 47

column1: 47,Enforce Inverse Relationships
column2: The Enforce Inverse Relationship option indicates whether to enforce the automatic calculation of inverse conversion rates when defining daily rates. The following table describes the impact of selecting or not selecting the option.,"The inverse rate is calculated, but you can change the rate and update the daily rates table without the corresponding rate being updated.",Header for Page 47

column1: 47,,Select Pivot Currencies,Header for Page 47

47,Select Pivot Currencies,"Select a pivot currency that's commonly used in your currency conversions. A pivot currency is the central currency that interacts with contra currencies. For example, you set up a daily rate between the US dollar (USD) and the Euro currency (EUR) and another between the USD and the Canadian dollar (CAD). USD is the pivot currency in creating a rate between EUR and CAD. EUR and CAD are the contra currencies. Select the pivot currency from the list of values which contains those currencies that are enabled, effective, and not a statistical (STAT) currency. The description of the pivot currency is populated automatically based on the currency definition.",Header for Page 47

47,Select Pivot Currencies,"If you want the application to create cross rates against a base currency, define the base currency as the pivot currency. Selected pivot currencies can be changed in the Rate Types page.",Header for Page 47
47,,Select Contra Currencies,Header for Page 47

47,Select Contra Currencies,"Select currencies available on the list of values as contra currencies. The available currencies are those currencies which are enabled, effective, not STAT currency, and not the pivot currency selected earlier. The description of the contra currency is populated automatically based on the currency definition. Add or delete contra currencies in the Contra Currencies region of the Rate Types page.",Header for Page 47
47,,Enable Cross Rates and Allow Cross Rate Overrides,Header for Page 47

47,Enable Cross Rates and Allow Cross Rate Overrides,"Check the Enable Cross Rates check box to calculate conversion rates based on defined currency rate relationships. General Ledger calculates cross rates based on your defined cross rate rules. Associate your cross rate rules with a conversion rate type, pivot currency, and contra currencies. Cross rates facilitate the creation of daily rates by automatically creating the rates between contra currencies based on their relationship to a pivot currency. If the Enable Cross Rates option is deselected after entering contra currencies, the application stops calculating cross rates going forward for that particular rate type. All the earlier calculated cross rates for that rate type remain in the database unless you manually delete them.",Header for Page 47

47,Enable Cross Rates and Allow Cross Rate Overrides,"For example, if you have daily rates defined for the pivot currency, USD to the contra currency, EUR, and USD to another contra currency, CAD, the application automatically creates the rates between EUR to CAD and CAD to EUR. You don't have to manually define the EUR to CAD and CAD to EUR rates.",Header for Page 47
47,Enable Cross Rates and Allow Cross Rate Overrides,39,Header for Page 47

48,,Chapter 3 Financial Reporting Structures,Header for Page 48

48,,"Select the Allow Cross Rates Override check box to permit your users to override application generated cross rates. If you accept the default of not selected, the application generated cross rates can't be overridden.",Header for Page 48
48,,Maintain Cross Rate Rules,Header for Page 48

48,Maintain Cross Rate Rules,"Define or update your cross rate rules at any time by adding or removing contra currency assignments. Add a contra currency to a cross rate rule and run the Daily Rates Import and Calculation process to generate the new rates. If you remove a cross rate rule or a contra currency from a rule, any cross rates generated previously for that contra currency remain unless you manually delete them. Changes to the rule aren't retroactive and don't affect previously stored cross rates. The Cross Rate process generates as many rates as possible and skips currencies where one component of the set is missing.",Header for Page 48

48,Maintain Cross Rate Rules,"Note: With a defined web service that extracts daily currency conversion rates from external services, for example Reuters, currency conversion rates are automatically updated for the daily rates and all cross currency relationships.",Header for Page 48

Select the USD - US Dollar list item. 6. Enter the dates for the daily rates that you are changing. Enter today's date. 7. Click the Rate Type list. Select the Spot list item.,Header for Page 50

53,4 Ledgers
column2: Overview of Ledger and Subledgers,Oracle Fusion Applications reflect the traditional segregation between the general ledger and associated subledgers. Detailed transactional information is captured in the subledgers and periodically imported and posted in summary or detail to the ledger.,Header for Page 53

column1: 53,4 Ledgers
column2: Overview of Ledger and Subledgers,"A ledger determines the currency, chart of accounts, accounting calendar, ledger processing options, and accounting method for its associated subledgers. Each accounting setup requires a primary ledger and optionally, one or more secondary ledgers and reporting currencies. Reporting currencies are associated with either a primary or secondary ledger.",Header for Page 53

column1: 53,4 Ledgers
column2: Overview of Ledger and Subledgers,The number of ledgers and subledgers is unlimited and determined by your business structure and reporting requirements.,Header for Page 53

column1: 53,4 Ledgers
column3: What happens if I change the cumulative translation adjustment account?,"Changing the cumulative translation adjustment (CTA) account is a very significant revision to your accounting configuration and should be avoided if possible. To prevent data corruption, your CTA can only be changed if you delete translated balances.",Header for Page 53
