210,,Analyze Journal Entry,Header for Page 210
210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: To correct the account on a subledger journal you must have the Override Subledger Journal Entry (XLA_OVERRIDE_SUBLEDGER_JOURNAL_ENTRY_PRIV) privilege.,"Using analyze journal entry feature, you can understand how the accounting engine evaluates the different rules, conditions, and accounting attribute assignments to derive the journal header and lines in an accounting entry.",Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: To correct the account on a subledger journal you must have the Override Subledger Journal Entry (XLA_OVERRIDE_SUBLEDGER_JOURNAL_ENTRY_PRIV) privilege.,"You can view the source values and understand how a particular condition, formula got evaluated successfully between others or why a particular rule priority was evaluated successfully. This can help you diagnose any rule setup-related accounting errors or explain why the accounting entries were generated in a specific manner.",Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry,Enable Feature,Header for Page 210
210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: Enable Feature,Here are the steps to enable analyze journal entry feature:,Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: Enable Feature,"1. From the Navigator menu, select Tools > Security Console. 2. Navigate to the Roles tab and click on the Create Role button. 3. Enter basic role information and select Role Category > Financials - Job Roles. 4. Navigate to the Function Security Policies train stop and add the function security policy > Review Accounting Diagnostic. 5. Navigate to the Users train stop and add the user to which you want to provide access to the Analyze Journal Entry page. 6. Navigate to Summary train stop and click on the Save and Close button. 7. From the Navigator menu, select Tools > Scheduled Processes. 8. Click on the Schedule New Process button, search and submit the process > Import User and Role Application Security Data.",Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry,Navigate to Analyze Journal Entry Page,Header for Page 210
210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: Navigate to Analyze Journal Entry Page,You can navigate to the Analyze Journal Entry page in the following ways:,Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: Navigate to Analyze Journal Entry Page,From View Accounting pop-up window,Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: Navigate to Analyze Journal Entry Page,You can navigate to the Analyze Journal Entry page from the existing View Accounting pop-up window accessible from the Subledger Transaction pages after accounting transactions in Draft or Final status. You can,Header for Page 210

column1: 210,Analyze Journal Entry
column2: Navigate to Analyze Journal Entry Page,202,Header for Page 210

column1: 211,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 211
211,,Chapter 7 Subledger Accounting,Header for Page 211
211,,select any journal line in the window and click on the Analyze Journal Entry button to view the specific journal line analysis.,Header for Page 211

211,,"Note: The View Accounting window may display journal lines of multiple event classes or event types which could pertain to different journal entries; however, the Analyze Journal Entry page is always displayed in the context of a specific journal entry. So, all journal lines displayed in the View Accounting window may not always be displayed on the Analyze Journal Entry page.",Header for Page 211
211,,From Review Journal Entries page,Header for Page 211

211,,"You can also navigate to the Analyze Journal Entry page from the existing Review Journal Entries page, which is accessible from the Subledger Transaction or the General Accounting Journals Work area, after accounting transactions in Draft or Final status. To navigate to the Analyze Journal Entry page, query any journal entry using the search parameters and then select the record in the Search Results table. Click on the Analyze Journal Entry button in the Journal Entry Details section to view the specific journal entry analysis.",Header for Page 211
211,,From Manage Accounting Errors page,Header for Page 211

211,,"You can also navigate to the Analyze Journal Entry page from the new Manage Accounting Errors page, which is accessible from the General Ledger Journals Work area, after accounting transactions in Draft or Final status. To navigate to the Analyze Journal Entry page, query accounting errors using the search parameters, select the appropriate record in the Search Results table and click on the Analyze Journal Entry button.",Header for Page 211

211,,Note: You can view Journal Entry Analysis for Invalid accounting entries if a journal entry was created for the event. No details would be displayed if a journal entry creation was unsuccessful.,Header for Page 211
211,,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,Header for Page 211

211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,"Every Subledger Journal Entry consists of a journal header and its corresponding journal lines. The Analyze Journal Entry page is divided into two tabs - The Journal Header tab and the Journal Lines tab, which render details about subledger accounting rules used in the subledger journal header vis-a-vis in the subledger journal lines region.",Header for Page 211
211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,The Journal Header tab displays the following information about the journal entry :,Header for Page 211

211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,"Overall Information about the Subledger Journal Entry is displayed in the topmost section. It displays details of the Subledger Accounting Method, Journal Entry Rule Set, and other details for the specific Event Class and Event Type.",Header for Page 211
211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,"Subledger Accounting Rules section displays the Description Rule, and Accounting Attributes information in 2 different sub-tabs.",Header for Page 211
211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,The Description Rule tab displays the description rule details used to generate the Journal Entry Description.,Header for Page 211

211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,The Accounting Attributes tab displays the journal header related accounting attributes (For example: Accounting Date) along with the source values used.,Header for Page 211
211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,Rule Details section is a child section of the Subledger Accounting Rules section displaying further details about a rule.,Header for Page 211
211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,"In a specific Description Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Priorities and Formula defined in the description rule.",Header for Page 211

211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,You can view the evaluation status of the priorities and review the source values to understand why a specific rule priority got applied successfully.,Header for Page 211
211,Subledger Journal Header Analysis,203,Header for Page 211
212,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 212
212,,Chapter 7 Subledger Accounting,Header for Page 212
212,,Subledger Journal Lines Analysis,Header for Page 212

212,Subledger Journal Lines Analysis,The Journal Lines tab displays details about subledger accounting rules used to generate all the journal lines for a specific journal entry. The page follows a hierarchical structure where you can select specific records in the upper sections to view the subledger accounting rules and further details in child sections.,Header for Page 212
212,Subledger Journal Lines Analysis,The Journal Lines tab displays the following information :,Header for Page 212

212,Subledger Journal Lines Analysis,"The Journal Lines section is displayed as the topmost section, and it shows all the journal lines for the subledger journal entry being analyzed.",Header for Page 212

212,Subledger Journal Lines Analysis,The Source Distribution section is a child section of the Journal Lines section. It displays all the distributions that were merged to generate a specific journal line. A single record would be displayed with line-level details for subledgers where distribution level information isn't captured,Header for Page 212

212,,"This section has a custom implementation for Payables and Receivables (exceptions include - Bills Receivable transactions) distributions fetching the distribution details from their respective distribution tables. For other subledgers, a generic layout has been used to display the source distribution identifiers and distribution type, and distribution amount.",Header for Page 212

212,"This section has a custom implementation for Payables and Receivables (exceptions include - Bills Receivable transactions) distributions fetching the distribution details from their respective distribution tables. For other subledgers, a generic layout has been used to display the source distribution identifiers and distribution type, and distribution amount.","Subledger Accounting Rules section is a child section of the Source Distribution section. It displays the Journal Line Rule, Description Rule, Account and\or Segment Rules, and Supporting Reference details in different sub- tabs, which were used for a specific source distribution.",Header for Page 212

212,,"Journal Line Rules tab displays the journal line rule details used to generate the specific journal line. Description Rules tab displays the description rule details, which were used to generate the Journal Line Description. The Account Rules tab displays all the account and\or segment rules, generating the account combination on the journal line. The Supporting References tab displays the supporting reference details along with the source value used.",Header for Page 212

212,"Journal Line Rules tab displays the journal line rule details used to generate the specific journal line. Description Rules tab displays the description rule details, which were used to generate the Journal Line Description. The Account Rules tab displays all the account and\or segment rules, generating the account combination on the journal line. The Supporting References tab displays the supporting reference details along with the source value used.",Special Cases \ Exceptions:,Header for Page 212

212,,"For business flow based accounting entries, since the account or description may be based on a related accounting entry from the upstream transaction, no subledger accounting rules would be displayed. For reversal accounting entries where the subledger uses a transaction or line reversal, a message will be displayed indicating the entry was generated due to reversal. For certain other cases (Multi-period Accounting, Account Override, Intercompany or Intracompany Balancing, Entered Currency, Balancing, and so on) where the accounting entry is system generated and no subledger accounting rules are used in the process, a message will be displayed indicating the same.",Header for Page 212

212,"For business flow based accounting entries, since the account or description may be based on a related accounting entry from the upstream transaction, no subledger accounting rules would be displayed. For reversal accounting entries where the subledger uses a transaction or line reversal, a message will be displayed indicating the entry was generated due to reversal. For certain other cases (Multi-period Accounting, Account Override, Intercompany or Intracompany Balancing, Entered Currency, Balancing, and so on) where the accounting entry is system generated and no subledger accounting rules are used in the process, a message will be displayed indicating the same.",Rule Details section is a child section of the Subledger Accounting Rules section displaying further details about any specific rule.,Header for Page 212

212,,"In the context of a specific Journal Line Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Condition, Advanced Options, Accounting Attributes, and Formula defined in the journal line rule. In a specific Description Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Priorities and Formula defined in the description rule. In a specific Account or Segment Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Priorities and Formula defined in the account or segment rule. In the Supporting References tab, the Rule Details section displays the formula defined in the supporting references.",Header for Page 212

212,"In the context of a specific Journal Line Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Condition, Advanced Options, Accounting Attributes, and Formula defined in the journal line rule. In a specific Description Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Priorities and Formula defined in the description rule. In a specific Account or Segment Rule, the Rule Details section displays the Priorities and Formula defined in the account or segment rule. In the Supporting References tab, the Rule Details section displays the formula defined in the supporting references.",204,Header for Page 212

213,,Projected Balances,Header for Page 213
213,"Projected Balances
column2: You can view the evaluation status of the priorities, review the source values to understand why a specific rule priority or condition got applied successfully.",Use the projected balances feature to view the impact on account balances for selected subledger journal entry lines.,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,"Projected Balances
column2: You can view the evaluation status of the priorities, review the source values to understand why a specific rule priority or condition got applied successfully.",The projected balances flow has the following business benefits:,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,"Projected Balances
column2: You can view the evaluation status of the priorities, review the source values to understand why a specific rule priority or condition got applied successfully.",The creation and validation of unposted manual journal entries by providing immediate information about the account balances for the selected journal lines.,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,"Projected Balances
column2: You can view the evaluation status of the priorities, review the source values to understand why a specific rule priority or condition got applied successfully.",The validation and reconciliation of posted journal entries by providing immediate information about the account balances for the selected journal lines.,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Projected Balances,Projected Balances,Header for Page 213
213,Projected Balances
column2: Projected Balances,"Subledger Accounting manual journal entry and General Ledger manual journal entry, approval, and inquiry pages display projected or current balances including the current journal entry line amounts. Depending on whether the journal is posted or not, the current balance (for the period of the journal) is displayed or calculated.",Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Projected Balances
column2: Projected Balances,"The projected balance region displays the projected balances for the account that includes the amounts of the selected journal entry line. Additionally, if more than one journal line for same account of the selected journal line exists, then the projected balance amount includes the impact from each journal line. The Period To Date, Quarter To Date, and Year To Date balances are also available.",Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Projected Balances
column2: Projected Balances,"For unposted journals, the period balance is projected by summing the current balance with the subledger journal entry line amounts",Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Projected Balances
column2: Projected Balances,"For posted journals, the opening balance and the period activity are calculated using the current balance and journal line amount",Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Projected Balances
column2: Projected Balances,Projected balances increases accuracy when booking entries to reconcile accounts.,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,,Manage Accounting Reversals,Header for Page 213
213,Manage Accounting Reversals
column2: Projected Balances,"To create an accounting reversal for a transaction or transaction distribution, the transaction objects should include the appropriate header or line level accounting reversal options.",Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Manage Accounting Reversals
column2: Projected Balances,Accounting reversals enables you to reverse the accounting impact of a previously accounted transaction distribution or all existing accounting for a transaction.,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Manage Accounting Reversals
column2: Projected Balances,Accounting reversal terminology includes the following:,Header for Page 213

column1: 213,Manage Accounting Reversals

213,Manage Accounting Reversals,"Refers to a transaction distribution that although successfully accounted, is either incorrect or canceled. The transaction distribution is therefore reversed.",Header for Page 213

214,,"Refers to a transaction distribution which reverses the effect of the original distribution on transaction balances. Typically, reversal distributions are identical to the reversed distributions in all respects except for entered (ledger) amounts that reverse the sign of the original.",Header for Page 214

214,"Refers to a transaction distribution which reverses the effect of the original distribution on transaction balances. Typically, reversal distributions are identical to the reversed distributions in all respects except for entered (ledger) amounts that reverse the sign of the original.",Replacement Distribution,Header for Page 214
214,,Refers to a transaction distribution which replaces the reversed distribution with the correct value.,Header for Page 214

column1: 215,Subledger Balances
column3: The following predefined attributes cannot be updated.,"The Import Supporting Reference Initial Balances spreadsheet lets you upload the initial balances for Supporting References. The initial balance is the starting balance for a supporting reference in the context of an application, ledger, and account combination.",Header for Page 215

column1: 215,Subledger Balances
column3: The following predefined attributes cannot be updated.,"Note: When using the Manage Configuration Packages task to export or import setup data, initial balances that have been imported into one environment aren't going to be migrated into another. You must import balances separately into each environment you maintain.",Header for Page 215

column1: 215,Subledger Balances
column3: The following predefined attributes cannot be updated.,Access the task from the Setup and Maintenance work area.,Header for Page 215

column1: 215,Subledger Balances
column3: The following predefined attributes cannot be updated.,Initialize Supporting Reference Balances when no balances exist,Header for Page 215

column1: 215,Subledger Balances
column3: The following predefined attributes cannot be updated.,"Let's say you already maintain a balance for certain dimensions in the legacy system which aren't available in Oracle Fusion and want to bring in those balances when migrating to Oracle Fusion Cloud ERP. Let's assume supporting reference balances are to be initialized against the supporting references - Account Number, Customer Category, Line Type, Country Code, State Code as follows:",Header for Page 215

219,,Update Subledger Accounting Balances Process,Header for Page 219

219,Update Subledger Accounting Balances Process,Use the Update Subledger Accounting Balances process (XLABABUP) to update subledger supporting reference balances and third-party control account balances.,Header for Page 219

219,Update Subledger Accounting Balances Process,This process is run automatically following the Create Accounting process. It should be run manually if the auto run fails for any reason.,Header for Page 219
219,Update Subledger Accounting Balances Process,Run the report from the Scheduled Processes page and optionally schedule the process to run periodically.,Header for Page 219
219,Update Subledger Accounting Balances Process,"Note: Draft entries do not update balances. To include accurate balances, transactions must be accounted in Final.",Header for Page 219
219,Update Subledger Accounting Balances Process,Parameters,Header for Page 219

column2: Parameters,List of all user accessible accounting generating subledgers.,Header for Page 219

column2: Parameters,"The list of ledgers is based on the user accessible business units, asset books or legal entities. Only the list of ledgers associated with those business units, asset books or legal entities is shown.",Header for Page 219

219,Carry Forward Subledger Accounting Balances Process
column2: Parameters,The Carry Forward Subledger Accounting Balances process will carry forward supporting reference balances and third- party control account balances to the current period for a ledger. This process is automatically initiated when the accounting period is newly opened.,Header for Page 219

column1: 219,Carry Forward Subledger Accounting Balances Process
column2: Parameters,Note: The process can also be submitted manually if the initial process executed abnormally when the accounting period was opened.,Header for Page 219

column1: 219,Carry Forward Subledger Accounting Balances Process,Parameters,Header for Page 219

column2: Parameters,"The list of ledgers is based on the business units, asset books or legal entities that a subledger user has access to. Only the list of ledgers associated with those business units, asset books or legal entities is shown.",Header for Page 219

220,Advanced Features,Accounting Class Usages,Header for Page 220
220,Advanced Features
column2: Accounting Class Usages,Accounting class usages is a classification or grouping of accounting event classes to be used in a report or process based on subledger journal entries.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column2: Accounting Class Usages,A report or process referring to such a group would only process subledger journal entries tagged with the accounting event classes defined in the group.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column2: Accounting Class Usages,Manage Accounting Class Usages Task,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Manage Accounting Class Usages Task,"The Manage Accounting Class Usages task enables you to group accounting event classes. Use Accounting Class Usages assignments to determine which subledger journal entry lines to retrieve for a particular process. For example, for mass additions a subledger can define accounting class usages to identify the journal entry lines that must be processed to create records for another subledger.",Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column2: Accounting Class Usages,Defining Accounting Class Usages,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,"Use the Manage Accounting Class Usages task to create assignments that may be associated with a ledger. In the Accounting Class Assignments region, assign accounting classes to an assignment definition.",Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,Predefined processes and assignment definitions cannot be deleted or updated. You can copy a predefined assignment definition and modify if necessary.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features,Accrual Reversals in Accounting Hub,Header for Page 220
220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,"To use accrual reversal, you assign application or standard date sources to the Accrual Reversal Accounting Date Source accounting attribute. When this accounting attribute has a value, the Create Accounting process generates an entry that reverses the accrual entry.",Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,Here's what you do to define how and when accrual reversals are automatically performed:,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,Indicate that an accounting event is eligible for accrual reversal.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,Determine when the accrual is reversed.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,Schedule the Create Accrual Reversal Accounting process to generate the reversal entries of the accrual.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,Note: You must not enable reversal in General Ledger journal for the journal source and category if accrual reversal is implemented in subledger.,Header for Page 220

column1: 220,Advanced Features
column3: Defining Accounting Class Usages,212,Header for Page 220

222,,Chapter 7 Subledger Accounting,Header for Page 222
222,,1. Assign a date source to the Accrual Reversal Accounting Date Source accounting attribute at the event class level.,Header for Page 222

222,,"Use this attribute to schedule the automatic reversal of a journal entry. On the Manage Accounting Attributes page, assign any standard date source or one of these application sources to the Accrual Reversal Accounting Date Source accounting attribute as a nondefault assignment:",Header for Page 222

222,,Next Day: The accounting date of the accrual reversal is the next day following the accounting date of the accrual entry. First Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the first day of the following accounting period. Last Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the last day of the following accounting period.,Header for Page 222

222,Next Day: The accounting date of the accrual reversal is the next day following the accounting date of the accrual entry. First Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the first day of the following accounting period. Last Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the last day of the following accounting period.,"Note: If a default source is assigned to the Accrual Reversal Accounting Date Source accounting attribute, it will be assigned to all the journal entry rule set defined for the event class.",Header for Page 222

222,Next Day: The accounting date of the accrual reversal is the next day following the accounting date of the accrual entry. First Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the first day of the following accounting period. Last Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the last day of the following accounting period.,2. Define a journal entry rule set for the event type for which you would like to use the accrual reversal feature and select an accrual reversal accounting date source. 3. Import Accounting Transaction with accrual transactions. 4. The Import Accounting Transaction process automatically submits the Create Accounting process that creates both accrual and reversal journal entries.,Header for Page 222

222,Next Day: The accounting date of the accrual reversal is the next day following the accounting date of the accrual entry. First Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the first day of the following accounting period. Last Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the last day of the following accounting period.,"If that accrual entry has exceptions, you must resolve the exceptions and then manually submit the Create Accounting process again.",Header for Page 222

222,Next Day: The accounting date of the accrual reversal is the next day following the accounting date of the accrual entry. First Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the first day of the following accounting period. Last Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the last day of the following accounting period.,"For all valid accrual journal entries, the Create Accounting process also creates the accrual reversal journal entry. Reversals can either be done by switching the debit and credit side on entries or by using negative amounts. You use the Reversal Method option on the Manage Subledger Accounting Options page to specify the method to use for reversals.",Header for Page 222

222,Next Day: The accounting date of the accrual reversal is the next day following the accounting date of the accrual entry. First Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the first day of the following accounting period. Last Day of Next Accounting Period: The accounting date of the accrual reversal entry is the last day of the following accounting period.,Here are the factors that affect the status of the accrual reversal journal entry:,Header for Page 222

224,Example 2,"Future trading requires a margin account that's market-to-market on a daily basis. This means that the investor or ledger's gains or losses on the position are reflected on a daily basis. If the margin account is less than a specified amount (the maintenance of the margin), a margin call is issued. This requires the holder of the account to replenish the account to the initial margin level or close out the position.",Header for Page 224
224,Example 2,The investor or ledger must mark the account to market each day. The entry booked from the day before must be reversed to reflect the new position.,Header for Page 224

Subledger Application
column2: Source system for which the Create Accrual Reversal Accounting process is being executed.

column1: Ledger
column2: Ledger name for which the Create Accrual Reversal Accounting process is being executed.

column1: Process Category
column2: The process category indicates that all associated accounting event classes and their accounting event

column1: types are selected for processing.
End Date
column2: End date puts a filter on the selection of journal entries. Only incomplete journal entries having an

column1: accounting date on or before the end date are selected for accounting.
Default value is current system date.
Process Events
column2: Adds other filter criteria for the Create Accounting process to specific events:

column1: • All: Process all incomplete journal entries and meets the End Date selection criteria
• Errors: Process only those entries that have previously been processed in error.
• Invalid Accounts: Process only those events that have previously been processed in error. Replace
any invalid accounts with the suspense account.
Default value is All.
Report
column2: Identify the type of details to display on the execution report. The report can be printed in Summary,

column1: Detail, or No report.
Default value is Summary.
Transfer to General Ledger
column2: Indicates whether the Create Accrual Reversal Accounting process should submit the Transfer to GL

column1: process; Yes, No.
Default value is Yes.
Post in General Ledger
column2: Indicates whether to submit General Ledger posting after Transfer to GL process is complete.

column1: Default value is Yes."

226,How You Submit the Create Accrual Reversal Accounting Process,The Create Accrual Reversal Accounting process processes incomplete accrual reversal journal entries with accounting dates that fall on or before the End Date parameter specified.,Header for Page 226

226,How You Submit the Create Accrual Reversal Accounting Process,"If the incomplete accrual reversal accounting entries are validated successfully, they're set to Final status and then posted to the general ledger, dependent on the parameters.",Header for Page 226

227,Multiperiod Accounting,Multiperiod accounting enables you to create accounting entries across more than one accounting period for a single accounting event. The functionality is primarily used to defer the recognition of revenue or prepaid expense across multiple accounting periods.,Header for Page 227

232,Where the:,- Multiperiod Recognized Entered Amount is calculated and stored in the Accounting Hub data model as the total amount recognized for the transaction in prior periods. The approach handles any rounding differences in prorated entered currency amounts.,Header for Page 232

232,Sample User-Defined Formulas,""" Multiperiod Original Entered Amount"" * NumberofGLPeriod (""Origination Date"", ""Last Day of Current Accounting Period"") / NumberofGLPeriod (""Origination Date"", ""Maturity Date"")",Header for Page 232

233,Using Multiperiod Accounting for Foreign Currency,"In the multiperiod accounting journal for foreign currency, the accounted amount is derived from the accrued amount / entered amount on the accrual line.",Header for Page 233
233,Using Multiperiod Accounting for Foreign Currency,"To calculate the accounted amount for multiperiod recognition entries, follow this logic:",Header for Page 233

233,Using Multiperiod Accounting for Foreign Currency,"1. Calculate the unrounded entered amount to be recognized from the multiperiod start date to the last day of the current period. 2. Calculate the unrounded entered amount to be recognized for the current period as Step 1 minus the total rounded entered amount from all multiperiod recognition lines in previous periods. 3. Calculate the unrounded accounted amount for the current period as Step 2* accrual accounted amount/ accrual entered amount. 4. The last multiperiod recognition entry will include a rounding difference, so it's calculated as: 'accrual amount' minus 'total amount from all multiperiod recognition lines in previous periods', for both entered and accounted amounts.",Header for Page 233
233,Using Multiperiod Accounting for Foreign Currency,225,Header for Page 233

235,,Prerequisites,Header for Page 235
235,Prerequisites,Provide date format sources to store the multiperiod start and end dates in transaction objects.,Header for Page 235
235,Prerequisites,"For the event class that supports multiperiod accounting, assign these sources to the accounting attributes:",Header for Page 235
235,,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Header for Page 235

235,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Define the multiperiod class in the subledger accounting lookup. The multiperiod class is used to identify the journal line for which the amount is prorated across multiple accounting periods.,Header for Page 235

235,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Tip: Accounted amounts for multiperiod journals are calculated by the Create Multiperiod Accounting process prorating proportionally to the entered amount. Rounding error differences are included in the prorated amount. Multiperiod transaction data must be available in transaction objects until the last multiperiod entry has been accounted in final status.,Header for Page 235
235,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Related Topics,Header for Page 235
235,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Multiperiod Accounting,Header for Page 235
235,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting,Header for Page 235
235,Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,Manage User-Defined Formulas,Header for Page 235
235,,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting,Header for Page 235
235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Multiperiod Start Date Multiperiod End Date,"To achieve a successful implementation of multiperiod accounting feature in Accounting Hub, the following points must be taken into consideration.",Header for Page 235

column1: 235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting,Determine when to raise a new accounting event,Header for Page 235
235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Determine when to raise a new accounting event,Determine when a new accounting event must be raised throughout the life cycle of a multiperiod transaction.,Header for Page 235

column1: 235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Determine when to raise a new accounting event,"If only the multiperiod start and end dates are changed, a new accounting event isn't required. As the transaction object is maintained to provide the new multiperiod start date, the impact of the change is reflected in the next multiperiod journal.",Header for Page 235

column1: 235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Determine when to raise a new accounting event,"Raise a new accounting event if the amount is changed, or a transaction is canceled after the transaction is accounted in a Final status.",Header for Page 235

column1: 235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Determine when to raise a new accounting event,"If the multiperiod start date is changed after the transaction is accounted, it's not necessary to raise a new accounting event. The assumption is that all other transaction attributes remain the same. If the transaction object is maintained to provide the new multiperiod start date, the impact of the change is reflected in the next multiperiod journal. This depends on the prorate method and is also true for future journal entries.",Header for Page 235

column1: 235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Determine when to raise a new accounting event,"However, if the transaction amount is changed after the transaction is accounted; the new accounting event is needed, which affects the total deferral amount.",Header for Page 235

column1: 235,Considerations for Multiperiod Accounting
column2: Determine when to raise a new accounting event,227,Header for Page 235

column1: 236,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 236
236,,Chapter 7 Subledger Accounting,Header for Page 236
236,,Tip: We suggest a detailed analysis be performed to determine whether to raise a new accounting event when transaction attributes are updated.,Header for Page 236
236,,Raise a transaction reversal event,Header for Page 236
236,Raise a transaction reversal event,Consider the multiperiod journal accounting date when raising the transaction reversal event.,Header for Page 236

236,Raise a transaction reversal event,"Set the reversal accounting date to a date after the last multiperiod journal with Final status. A reversal entry reverses all existing final entries, including the multiperiod journals, with the reversal accounting date.",Header for Page 236

236,Raise a transaction reversal event,"For example, the transaction accounting date is on 01-Feb and multiperiod journals have been created for February and March with a Final status. If the transaction is canceled, the cancellation event should be set to 01-Apr or the first day of the next open period, whichever is later.",Header for Page 236
236,,Provide the multiperiod start and end dates,Header for Page 236

236,Provide the multiperiod start and end dates,The multiperiod start date and multiperiod end date must be provided in transaction objects for event classes that support multiperiod accounting. These date sources are mapped to the accounting attributes Multiperiod Start Date and Multiperiod End Date for the event class. They must both be blank or both be populated in the transaction objects.,Header for Page 236

236,Provide the multiperiod start and end dates,"Once a multiperiod journal is created in Final status, the multiperiod end date should not be modified to any day prior to the accounting date of the last multiperiod journal in the primary and secondary ledgers.",Header for Page 236
236,,Deferring the multiperiod end date,Header for Page 236

236,Deferring the multiperiod end date,"When you're deferring the multiperiod end date, then the recognition amount has to be adjusted. As the recognition line isn't generated based on the journal line rule, the switch debit and credit option isn't applicable. The appropriate offsetting entry for the positive or negative amount is generated to offset the extra recognition.",Header for Page 236

236,Deferring the multiperiod end date,"For example, if you're extending for 3 months and have already run the multiperiod accounting for the first 2 months, you would have recognized more than the amount required to offset; hence a negative entry will be generated.",Header for Page 236
236,,Provide the multiperiod transaction data,Header for Page 236

236,Provide the multiperiod transaction data,Multiperiod transaction data must be available in subledger transaction objects until the last multiperiod entry is accounted in Final status.,Header for Page 236

236,Provide the multiperiod transaction data,"At least one line level transaction object is required for the event class to use multiperiod feature. Ensure transaction objects are populated with current data for the multiperiod transaction throughout the life cycle of multiperiod, even if the transaction is accounted.",Header for Page 236

236,Provide the multiperiod transaction data,"For example, if the multiperiod start date is changed after the transaction is accounted but not all future entries have been accounted. The new multiperiod start date should be populated in the transaction object. This enables the Create Multiperiod Accounting process to calculate the prorate amount according to the modified multiperiod date range.",Header for Page 236
236,,Process the multiperiod accounting,Header for Page 236

236,Process the multiperiod accounting,Multiperiod recognition entries are created based on transaction objects data and accounting rule definition at the time the Create Multiperiod Accounting process is executed.,Header for Page 236

236,Process the multiperiod accounting,The entered amount value for the multiperiod journal is calculated by a formula. This formula is assigned to the Entered Amount accounting attribute on the multiperiod journal line rule.,Header for Page 236

236,Process the multiperiod accounting,"The accounted amount value for multiperiod journals is calculated by the Create Multiperiod Accounting process, prorating proportionally to the entered amount, including rounding differences.",Header for Page 236
236,Process the multiperiod accounting,228,Header for Page 236
237,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 237
237,,Chapter 7 Subledger Accounting,Header for Page 237
237,,Multiperiod accounting entries aren't created:,Header for Page 237
237,,"If any subledger level reporting currency or secondary ledger is disabled, although the multiperiod transaction may not be fully recognized yet.",Header for Page 237
237,,"If subledger level reporting currency is added after the journal is created in Final status, the multiperiod journal isn't created for the new reporting currency.",Header for Page 237

237,,"If the transaction accounting date is prior to the first open period of a reporting currency or secondary ledger, the journal isn't created for the reporting currency or secondary ledger.",Header for Page 237
237,,Multiperiod transactions are processed by the Create Multiperiod Accounting process only once for each accounting period and transaction.,Header for Page 237
237,,Don't modify the multiperiod start date for a transaction to a date in a prior accounting period of the last multiperiod journal in primary and secondary ledgers.,Header for Page 237

237,,"If the multiperiod start date for a transaction is modified to a date in a prior accounting period, accounting periods that were previously processed for the transaction by the Create Multiperiod Accounting process aren't processed, regardless of the period status. Any adjustment in the prorated amount due to change of start date will be accounted in the next accounting period.",Header for Page 237
237,,Related Topics,Header for Page 237
237,,Example of Multiperiod Accounting,Header for Page 237
237,,Multiperiod Accounting,Header for Page 237
237,,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries,Header for Page 237

237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries,The following sequences are attached to subledger journal entries or general ledger journal entries. These two sequences aren't mutually exclusive and can coexist in the same journal entry.,Header for Page 237
237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries,Accounting Sequence,Header for Page 237
237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries
column2: Accounting Sequence,The accounting sequence is assigned to subledger journal entries at the time that the journal entry is completed. The sequence is assigned in the completion date order using the accounting date as the date criterion for determining the sequence to be used.,Header for Page 237

column1: 237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries,Reporting Sequence,Header for Page 237
237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries
column2: Reporting Sequence,The reporting sequence is assigned to both subledger journal entries and general ledger journal entries when the accounting period is closed. This sequence is used by most of the legal reports required in some countries as the main sorting criterion to display the journal entries.,Header for Page 237

column1: 237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries
column2: Reporting Sequence,"Note: In some related documents, this sequence is referred to as the chronological sequence.",Header for Page 237

column1: 237,Overview of Sequencing of Accounting Entries

239,,Transaction Reversal,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,You can import a new transaction record to Accounting Hub to reverse the accounting of a transaction in the same batch or an existing transaction.,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,Make sure that the new transaction record includes these values:,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,The same transaction number as the transaction you want to reverse.,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,The value of the reversal indicator as Y.,Header for Page 239

239,Transaction Reversal,Here's what happens when you import the new transaction record. Accounting Hub generates a reversal accounting that offsets the accounting of the original transaction.,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,Note:,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,Line record is not needed when importing reversal records.,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,The GL date for the reversal should be prior to or the same as the GL date of the non-reversal journal entry.,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal,Example of Transaction Reversal,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Example of Transaction Reversal,"Let's say that an accounting transaction with transaction number 1001 is imported and accounted in Accounting Hub successfully. Later, this transaction is canceled in the source system.",Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Example of Transaction Reversal,"To reverse the accounting transaction created in Accounting Hub, you import a new accounting transaction with the same transaction number 1001 and set the reversal indicator as Y. After the new accounting transaction record is imported, Accounting Hub creates journal entries to offset the accounting effect from the original transaction.",Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal,Before You Start,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Before You Start,Here are some of the things you must do before you can start using transaction reversals:,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Before You Start,Enable the Flexible Configuration of the Accounting Flow feature.,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Before You Start,Opt in to enable this feature.,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Before You Start,Enable transaction reversal for subledgers that use this feature.,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Before You Start,Download and use the latest transaction template for the subledger.,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal,Other Implementation Considerations,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Other Implementation Considerations,"You might be wondering how to reverse a multiperiod accounting transaction. In such a case, make sure that the transaction date for the reversal record is on or after the accounting date of the last multiperiod accounting entry of the transaction being reversed.",Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal,Import Accounting Hub Reversal Transactions with User-Specified Reversal Date,Header for Page 239
239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Import Accounting Hub Reversal Transactions with User-Specified Reversal Date,You can configure an accounting rule to use a user-specified source as the reversal accounting date for Accounting Hub transactions. This provides you with the flexibility to use other date sources as the accounting date for both original and reversal transactions.,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Import Accounting Hub Reversal Transactions with User-Specified Reversal Date,You can configure the accounting date of subledger journal entries to not depend on the transaction date and use the accounting date for reversal transactions too.,Header for Page 239

column1: 239,Transaction Reversal
column2: Import Accounting Hub Reversal Transactions with User-Specified Reversal Date,231,Header for Page 239

Account Analysis Report
column2: Provides drill down information about the movement on a particular account for a period or range of

240,,"This feature lets you account for backdated transactions. Make sure you account for backdated transactions in the current period by keeping the original transaction date for reference. 240,,"Note: There's no need to import reversal in any specific order. If the reversal record is imported before the non- reversal record, the reversal will be held in the interface table. 242,"Subledger Accounting Subject Areas, Folders, and Attributes","To create real-time analyses for Oracle Fusion Subledger Accounting you should be familiar with subject areas, folders, and attributes.",Header for Page 242

242,"Subledger Accounting Subject Areas, Folders, and Attributes
column2: Subject Areas","To create an analysis, you begin by selecting a subject area from which you select columns of information to include in the analysis. For example, to create an analysis of journal information, you begin by selecting a Subledger Accounting- Journals Real Time subject area. Subject areas are based around a business object or fact. In this example, the subject area is based on the column in the subledger entries tables.",Header for Page 242

242,"Subledger Accounting Subject Areas, Folders, and Attributes
column2: Folders","Each subject area has one fact folder and a number of dimension folders. Fact folders contain attributes that can be measured, meaning that they're numeric values like journal debit and credit amounts. Fact folders are in the list of folders and are usually named after the subject area. Dimension folders contain attribute and hierarchical columns like journal name and accounting period.",Header for Page 242

column1: 242,"Subledger Accounting Subject Areas, Folders, and Attributes
column2: Folders","Some folders appear in more than one subject area, such as Time. These are referred to as common folders or common dimensions.",Header for Page 242

column1: 242,"Subledger Accounting Subject Areas, Folders, and Attributes
column2: Folders",Each folder within a subject area may have a different level of granularity. For example:,Header for Page 242

247,,Chapter 7 Subledger Accounting,Header for Page 247
247,,Can I have subledger accounting entries in Adjustment Only ledgers?,Header for Page 247

247,Can I have subledger accounting entries in Adjustment Only ledgers?,"No, you can use Adjustment Only ledgers for General Ledger manual journals only. However, you can define a Subledger level secondary ledger with valuation method enabled and use it for subledger journal adjustments.",Header for Page 247

247,Can I have subledger accounting entries in Adjustment Only ledgers?,You can then create a ledger set to combine the secondary ledger with the primary ledger. Use the ledger set while running reports to obtain a complete accounting representation that includes both transactional data and adjustments.,Header for Page 247
247,,Can I import transactions into adjusting periods directly?,Header for Page 247

247,Can I import transactions into adjusting periods directly?,"No, you can import accounting transactions only to nonadjusting periods. However, you can create subledger journal adjustments in adjusting periods from the Create Subledger Journal Entry page. You can also upload subledger journal adjustments in adjusting periods using the Create Subledger Journals spreadsheet.",Header for Page 247
247,,Can I enable flexible configuration only for select subledger applications?,Header for Page 247

247,Can I enable flexible configuration only for select subledger applications?,"No. If you enable the Flexible Configuration of Accounting Hub Cloud Service End to End Flow feature, it applies to all subledger applications.",Header for Page 247
247,,Can I adjust accounting date when processing backdated transactions?,Header for Page 247

247,Can I adjust accounting date when processing backdated transactions?,"Backdated transactions would be accounted with errors if the corresponding accounting period is closed. You can delete invalid transactions, adjust dates in the data file, and import again.",Header for Page 247
247,Can I adjust accounting date when processing backdated transactions?,Related Topics,Header for Page 247
247,Can I adjust accounting date when processing backdated transactions?,Overview of Accounting Hub Maintenance,Header for Page 247
247,Can I adjust accounting date when processing backdated transactions?,Run the Accounting Hub Maintenance Process to Delete Transactions,Header for Page 247
247,,How do the Subledger Journal Entry Descriptions Get Translated?,Header for Page 247

247,How do the Subledger Journal Entry Descriptions Get Translated?,"In the journal entry description, the Journal Language determines which language is used to retrieve and store the subledger journal sources.",Header for Page 247
247,How do the Subledger Journal Entry Descriptions Get Translated?,239,Header for Page 247

248,,"In all predefined subledgers, multiple languages are supported, and as soon as the Create Accounting process is completed, the sources used in the description are retrieved and saved in the appropriate language. The translated source values used in the journal description will be retrieved using the session language of the user who submitted the Create Accounting process.",Header for Page 248

249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Processing Rules,"Define intercompany system options to set up intercompany processing rules at the enterprise level, based on your specific business needs.",Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Processing Rules,"To maintain consistency throughout an enterprise, intercompany transaction processing rules should be defined at the enterprise level. By standardizing these rules, an enterprise can minimize disputes, decrease processing time, and cut administrative costs.",Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Processing Rules,"Before setting up intercompany system options, you must determine how to process your intercompany transactions. For example, to:",Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Processing Rules,Enforce an enterprise-wide currency or allow intercompany transactions in local currencies.,Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules,Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,Header for Page 249
249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,Intercompany balancing rules are used to generate the accounts needed to balance journals that are out of balance by legal entity or primary balancing segment values.,Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,You specify the intercompany receivables and intercompany payables accounts that you want to use as the template for building the intercompany receivables and intercompany payables accounts. The intercompany balancing feature then uses these rules to generate the accounts of the balancing lines it creates.,Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,"Journals lines are first summarized by the legal entity and are balanced by the legal entity. Since a legal entity can have many primary balancing segment values, it's possible that a journal could have multiple lines for a legal entity with different primary balancing segment values. In that case, when intercompany balancing is done, the lowest primary balancing segment value within each legal entity in the journal is used. After this, balancing occurs across balancing segment values within each legal entity.",Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,These same rules are also used to generate the intercompany receivables account and intercompany payables account of transactions entered in the Intercompany module.,Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,The intercompany balancing rules are also used to generate the intercompany receivables account for the provider side of an intercompany transaction. The balancing rules also used to generate the intercompany payables account for the receiver side of an intercompany transaction.,Header for Page 249

column1: 249,8 Intercompany Processing Rules
column2: Overview of Intercompany Balancing Rules,241,Header for Page 249

250,Overview of Intercompany Allocations,The two processes you can use for intercompany allocation generation are Generate Intercompany Allocations and Generate General Ledger Allocations. You can use both processes for single-ledger allocations or cross-ledger allocations.,Header for Page 250

250,Overview of Intercompany Allocations,The Generate Intercompany Allocations process updates Oracle Fusion Intercompany tables. The Generate General Ledger Allocations process updates Oracle Fusion General Ledger tables.,Header for Page 250

column2: How can I use social networking to discuss intercompany allocation adjustments with cost center owners?,Use the social feature on the Intercompany Transactions work area to invite others to share information.,Header for Page 250

column1: 250,FAQs for Intercompany Allocations
column2: How can I use social networking to discuss intercompany allocation adjustments with cost center owners?,Here's how you use the social feature:,Header for Page 250

column1: 250,FAQs for Intercompany Allocations
column2: How can I use social networking to discuss intercompany allocation adjustments with cost center owners?,"1. Navigate to the Intercompany Transactions work area. 2. Search for the intercompany transaction. 3. Click Social and then click Share. Optionally, click Join to join an existing conversation. 4. Create a related conversation. And invite other cost center owners to join the conversation. 5. Upload the allocation spreadsheet for them to review. As cost center owners, you can post questions. And other cost center owners can see responses to the questions because they're owners.",Header for Page 250

column1: 250,FAQs for Intercompany Allocations
column2: How can I use social networking to discuss intercompany allocation adjustments with cost center owners?,Each cost center owner can validate their intercompany allocation in the conversation itself. This creates a lasting record.,Header for Page 250

column1: 250,FAQs for Intercompany Allocations
column2: How can I use social networking to discuss intercompany allocation adjustments with cost center owners?,242,Header for Page 250

251,Intercompany Reconciliation,Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,Header for Page 251
251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,Use the Reconciliation Report to reconcile your inner company accounts.,Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,Perform the following steps to generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report:,Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,"1. Navigate to the Springboard items from the landing page. 2. Click General Accounting Infolets. 3. On the IC Reconciliation infolet, click Reconcile Intercompany Accounts to start the Extract Intercompany Reconciliation process. 4. Click Actions and then click Run. 5. Select the value for the report parameters: Provider Ledger, Provider Accounting Period, and Additional Currency .",Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,Note: Ensure that the entries in the fields Provider Ledger and Provider Accounting Period match the ledger on the dashboard. The Additional Currency must also match the currency of the ledger on the dashboard.,Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,6. Select Conversion Rate Type and Conversion Date . These two parameters are enabled after you select the Additional Currency . 7. Click Submit . 8. Click Refresh until you see the report.,Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,Note: The Period summary report is displayed only after the Extract Intercompany Reconciliation process is completed.,Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,"9. Click Actions drop-down list and select History to view previously run reports in the Period Summary. If the Provider Legal Entity or Receiver Legal Entity is displayed as 'unassigned', it means the primary balancing segment value on the balancing line isn't assigned to a legal entity. 10. Select an item under Entered Amount Difference in Transaction Currency column to view the Summary by Source report. 11. Review Intercompany Receivables GL Balance and Intercompany Payables GL Balance in the Summary by Source report. Identify the roles which have a higher balance and the journal lines that are in one, but may not be in the other balance.",Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,"Note: If there is a difference between the Intercompany receivables and payables amounts, drill down further on both intercompany receivables and payables amounts to identify the journal lines that appear in one but not the other.",Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,"a. Click the line which appears in one but not the other. b. On the Journal Lines page, click the journal name to review it and determine if it has been correctly posted to the intercompany account. c. If the journal has been posted incorrectly, reverse it so that the Intercompany Receivables GL Balance and Intercompany Payables GL Balance accounts on Summary by Source report match.",Header for Page 251

column1: 251,Intercompany Reconciliation
column2: Generate the Intercompany Reconciliation Report,243,Header for Page 251

252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,Intercompany reconciliation provides you with reports to assist you with reconciling your intercompany receivables and intercompany payables accounts and identifying differences.,Header for Page 252

252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,The main goal of the reports is to make it easy for you to identify either the receiver side or provider side of a transaction that has not been posted to the intercompany receivables or intercompany payables account.,Header for Page 252
252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,The reports show the following intercompany lines:,Header for Page 252
252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,Intercompany receivables and intercompany payables lines generated by the intercompany balancing feature.,Header for Page 252
252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,Intercompany receivables and intercompany payables lines generated for the provider and receiver of each intercompany transaction.,Header for Page 252
252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,The following are not included on the intercompany reconciliation reports:,Header for Page 252

252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,Ledger balancing lines generated when the primary balancing segment value is in balance but either the second balancing segment or the third balancing segment is out of balance,Header for Page 252
252,Overview of Intercompany Reconciliation,Clearing company balancing lines,Header for Page 252

254,FAQs for Consolidations
column2: How can I secure balance transfer drill down?,The balance transfer drill-down feature is secured with the same privilege that controls the existing account balance inquiry features.,Header for Page 254

column1: 254,FAQs for Consolidations
column2: How can I secure balance transfer drill down?,"A specific data access set is not required to drill down from the target ledger to the source ledger to view the balance transfer information. As long as you have read or write access to the target ledger you can drill down to the source ledger. However, you are limited to just that drill path and cannot see other journals for the target ledger.",Header for Page 254

255,10 Budget Configuration
column2: Overview of Budget Configuration,"In Oracle General Ledger, you can load budget data to perform variance reporting.",Header for Page 255

column1: 255,10 Budget Configuration
column2: Overview of Budget Configuration,"If you use a third-party budgeting application or don't use a budgeting application, there are two ways to load budgets into the GL Balances Cube.",Header for Page 255

column1: 255,10 Budget Configuration
column2: Overview of Budget Configuration,"Importing Budget Data from a Flat File : Export budget data from your budgeting application to a comma separated values .csv file. Use the Import General Ledger Budget Balances file-based data import to prepare and generate flat files in a .csv format. You can use Oracle Application Development Framework Desktop Integrator correction worksheets to correct validation errors, delete rows with errors, and resubmit the corrected error rows.",Header for Page 255

column1: 255,10 Budget Configuration
column2: Overview of Budget Configuration,"Note: For more information about file-based data import, see the File-Based Data Import for Oracle Financials Cloud guide.",Header for Page 255

column1: 255,10 Budget Configuration
column2: Overview of Budget Configuration,"Importing Budget Data from a Spreadsheet : You can access the budget load spreadsheet from the General Accounting Dashboard. Enter, load, and correct budget data in the ADF Desktop Integrator spreadsheet tool. Use this tool to prepare and load budget data for multiple ledgers and periods with a common chart of accounts instance. The list of values and the web picker help you select valid values. This simplified data entry reduces errors and alerts you to errors as you enter the data in the spreadsheet. Error correction is done in the same spreadsheet.",Header for Page 255

column1: 255,10 Budget Configuration
column2: Overview of Budget Configuration,247,Header for Page 255

256,,"The following figure shows the process flow for budget upload. Prepare your budget data, upload it using a spreadsheet or flat file, and report on the budget data.",Header for Page 256

256,,"CAUTION: When the GL Balances Cube is rebuilt, the process retains the budget balances as well as the actual balances. Only the budget balances loaded using the spreadsheet or flat file through the GL Budget Balances interface table are retained. Create reports in Smart View or Financial Reporting to verify that the budget data was loaded correctly.",Header for Page 256

column1: 259,11 Financial Reporting
column3: How can I apply permissions to objects from Financial Reporting in Workspace?,"Permissions determine which user, group, or role can view, open, or modify the object. If you display this dialog box while working in the catalog in Workspace, any permission changes that you specify are applied immediately. If you display this dialog box as part of the Batch Scheduler wizard, then the permission changes aren't applied until you run the batch.",Header for Page 259

260,,"Only the financial reports in the /shared/Custom/Financials folder are exported, so make sure to copy all the financial reports, or the folders containing them, to this folder. In the Setup and Maintenance work area, create an implementation project that includes only the Create Financial Statements task. Then use the Manage Configuration Packages task to export and import the reports.",Header for Page 260

260,,"Note: For the Financial Reporting report definition migration service, from a source to a target environment, references to version IDs of dimension members hierarchies are synced to their version IDs in the target environment.",Header for Page 260

column2: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio,This is the first of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.,Header for Page 260

column1: 260,Create a Financial Report

column3: This is the first of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.,Watch video,Header for Page 260

column1: 260,Create a Financial Report
column2: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio,"You can use Financial Reporting Web Studio to design traditional financial report formats such as balance sheets, profit and loss statements, and cash flow reports. You can also design nontraditional reports for financial or analytic data that include text and graphics.",Header for Page 260

column1: 260,Create a Financial Report
column2: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio,"In this example, you're designing a basic financial report.",Header for Page 260

column1: 260,Create a Financial Report
column2: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio,"1. From the Financial Reporting Center work area, select the Tasks panel tab and click Open Workspace for Financial Reports . 2. On the Tools menu, select Launch Financial Reporting Web Studio . 3. On the File menu, select New , Report . 4. On the toolbar, click the Grid icon. Grids are tables that contain data from external database connections. 5. In the design canvas, draw a box to create the grid. The Database Connection Properties dialog box opens.",Header for Page 260

column1: 260,Create a Financial Report
column2: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio,"Tip: When creating a grid, best practice is to leave space in the design canvas for other objects, such as a company logo and report title.",Header for Page 260

column1: 260,Create a Financial Report
column2: Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio,252,Header for Page 260

column1: 261,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 261
261,,Chapter 11 Financial Reporting,Header for Page 261

261,,6. Select the Data Sources list and select the data source for the chart of accounts that the report is based on. A unique cube exists for each combination of chart of accounts and accounting calendar.,Header for Page 261

261,,"Tip: Best practice is to always turn on suppression in financial reports at the Database Connection Server level. You can verify the setting by highlighting the grid, and then selecting Data Query Optimization Settings on the Task menu. For most reports, best practice is to turn on suppression for the entire grid. Then turn suppression off for columns and rows that must always display. For more information about suppression settings, refer to the Defining Basic Conditional Suppression section in the Financial Reporting Web Studio User's guide.",Header for Page 261
261,,7. Click OK . The Dimension Layout dialog box opens.,Header for Page 261
261,,Arrange the Dimensions,Header for Page 261

261,Arrange the Dimensions,"Use the Dimension Layout dialog box to arrange the dimensions on your report. For this report, the accounting periods display on the columns and the revenue and expense account information displays on the rows. The company appears on each page and can be selected at runtime.",Header for Page 261

261,Arrange the Dimensions,1. Drag the Accounting Period dimension to the Columns axis. 2. Drag the Account dimension to the Rows axis. 3. Drag the Company dimension to the Page axis. 4. Click OK to close the Dimension Layout dialog box.,Header for Page 261
261,,Define the Rows,Header for Page 261
261,Define the Rows,Use the Select Members dialog box to define the revenue and expense account rows.,Header for Page 261
261,Define the Rows,1. Select the revenue parent account.,Header for Page 261

261,Define the Rows,"a. Double-click the Account cell. The Select Members dialog box opens with a default member selected. b. Remove the default Account selection from the Selected area by clicking it to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. c. In the Search field, enter the value for the account that represents total revenue and click the Search icon. d. Select the account from the search results and click OK . The account moves to the Selected area. e. Click OK . The Select Members dialog box closes. 2. Now insert a text row to add space between the revenue and expense accounts.",Header for Page 261
261,Define the Rows,"a. Select the last row in the grid by clicking the row header. b. On the Insert menu, select Row , then Text . 3. Insert a row for the expense accounts.",Header for Page 261

261,Define the Rows,"a. Right-click the last row header. b. On the Insert Row menu, select Data . Notice the default value for the new row is the revenue parent account. 4. Select the expense parent accounts.",Header for Page 261

261,Define the Rows,"a. Double-click the account value in the new expense account row. The Select Members dialog box opens with the revenue parent account selected. b. Remove the revenue parent account selection from the Selected area by clicking to select it and then clicking the Remove from Selected icon. c. In the Available area, expand the Account member, and continue expanding until you find the expense parent accounts for the report.",Header for Page 261
261,Define the Rows,253,Header for Page 261
262,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 262
262,,Chapter 11 Financial Reporting,Header for Page 262

262,,d. Select the accounts and click the Add to Selected icon to move them to the Selected area. e. Select the Place selections into separate rows option so each account appears in its own row on the report. f. Click OK . The Select Members dialog box closes.,Header for Page 262
262,,Save and Preview the Report,Header for Page 262
262,Save and Preview the Report,"Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is adding a formula to a financial report.",Header for Page 262

262,Save and Preview the Report,1. Click the Save icon. 2. Select the folder with your name and enter the report name and description. 3. Click Save . 4. Optionally preview the report in HTML or PDF format using the File menu or toolbar.,Header for Page 262
262,,Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report,Header for Page 262
262,Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,This is the second of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.,Header for Page 262

column1: 262,Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report
column3: This is the second of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.,Watch video,Header for Page 262

column1: 262,Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,"In this example, you define a formula to summarize the expense account balances on your financial report.",Header for Page 262

column1: 262,Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,"Before you start, do the steps described in the Define a Basic Financial Report Using the Reporting Web Studio topic, then follow these steps.",Header for Page 262

column1: 262,Add Formulas to a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,"1. Right-click the last row header, select Insert Row and select Formula . 2. Click in the empty cell in the new row. 3. In the Heading Row Properties pane, select the Custom Heading option, enter Total Expenses and click the Update icon. The new heading appears in the report. 4. Select the row header for the formula row. The SUM function appears in the design canvas. 5. In the Formula bar, click the Sum ( 0 ) button and enter the formula and cell references in the formula text box. Because the expense rows appear one after the other, you can use the first row number and the last row number with a colon in between. For example, Sum([3:5]). If the rows weren't contiguous, you could put brackets around each row number and separate them with commas. For example, Sum([3], [5], [6]). 6. Validate the formula syntax by clicking the check mark icon in the toolbar. Validation checks the validity of the formula, not if the data is available. 7. Save the report and leave it open for the next topic, which is defining a range function. Optionally preview the report.",Header for Page 262

column1: 262,,Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report,Header for Page 262
262,Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,This is the third of six topics on designing a financial report with Financial Reporting Web Studio.,Header for Page 262

column1: 262,Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,"In this example, you define a range function to report across multiple accounting periods. You configure the range to present balances for the last 12 months from the period selected at runtime.",Header for Page 262

column1: 262,Define Range Functions for a Financial Reporting Report
column2: Save and Preview the Report,254,Header for Page 262

column1: 263,,Oracle Fusion Cloud Financials Implementing Accounting Hub,Header for Page 263
